{"Status": "Complete", "Paper Overview": {"type_of_reference": "JOUR", "Title": "Hubble Frontier Fields: the geometry and dynamics of the massive galaxy cluster merger MACSJ0416.1-2403", "authors": ["Jauzac, Mathilde", "Jullo, Eric", "Eckert, Dominique", "Ebeling, Harald", "Richard, Johan", "Limousin, Marceau", "Atek, Hakim", "Kneib, Jean-Paul", "Cl\u00e9ment, Benjamin", "Egami, Eiichi", "Harvey, David", "Knowles, Kenda", "Massey, Richard", "Natarajan, Priyamvada", "Neichel, Beno\u00eet", "Rexroth, M."], "author_address": ["AA(Institute for Computational Cosmology, Durham University, South Road, Durham DH1 3LE, UK; Astrophysics and Cosmology Research Unit, School of Mathematical Sciences, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Durban 4041, South Africa), AB(Laboratoire d'Astrophysique de Marseille - LAM, Universit\u00e9 d'Aix-Marseille &amp; CNRS, UMR7326, 38 rue F. Joliot-Curie, F-13388 Marseille Cedex 13, France), AC(Astronomy Department, University of Geneva, 16 ch. d'Ecogia, CH-1290 Versoix, Switzerland), AD(Institute for Astronomy, University of Hawaii, 2680 Woodlawn Drive, Honolulu, HI 96822, USA), AE(CRAL, Observatoire de Lyon, Universit\u00e9 Lyon 1, 9 Avenue Ch. Andr\u00e9, F-69561 Saint Genis Laval Cedex, France), AF(Laboratoire d'Astrophysique de Marseille - LAM, Universit\u00e9 d'Aix-Marseille &amp; CNRS, UMR7326, 38 rue F. Joliot-Curie, F-13388 Marseille Cedex 13, France), AG(Laboratoise d'Astrophysique, Ecole Polytechnique F\u00e9d\u00e9rale de Lausanne (EPFL), Observatoire de Sauverny, CH-1290 Versoix, Switzerland), AH(Laboratoire d'Astrophysique de Marseille - LAM, Universit\u00e9 d'Aix-Marseille &amp; CNRS, UMR7326, 38 rue F. Joliot-Curie, F-13388 Marseille Cedex 13, France; Laboratoise d'Astrophysique, Ecole Polytechnique F\u00e9d\u00e9rale de Lausanne (EPFL), Observatoire de Sauverny, CH-1290 Versoix, Switzerland), AI(Steward Observatory, University of Arizona, 933 North Cherry Avenue, Tucson, AZ 85721, USA), AJ(Steward Observatory, University of Arizona, 933 North Cherry Avenue, Tucson, AZ 85721, USA), AK(SUPA, University of Edinburgh, Royal Observatory, Blackford Hill, Edinburgh EH9 3HJ, UK), AL(Astrophysics and Cosmology Research Unit, School of Mathematical Sciences, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Durban 4041, South Africa), AM(Institute for Computational Cosmology, Durham University, South Road, Durham DH1 3LE, UK), AN(Department of Astronomy, Yale University, 260 Whitney Avenue, New Haven, CT 06511, USA), AO(Laboratoire d'Astrophysique de Marseille - LAM, Universit\u00e9 d'Aix-Marseille &amp; CNRS, UMR7326, 38 rue F. Joliot-Curie, F-13388 Marseille Cedex 13, France), AP(Laboratoise d'Astrophysique, Ecole Polytechnique F\u00e9d\u00e9rale de Lausanne (EPFL), Observatoire de Sauverny, CH-1290 Versoix, Switzerland)"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "volume": "446", "publication_year": "2015/02/1", "start_page": "4132", "end_page": "4147", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "gravitational lensing: weak", "galaxies: clusters: individual:", "dark matter", "X-rays: galaxies: clusters", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2015MNRAS.446.4132J", "abstract": "We use a joint optical/X-ray analysis to constrain the geometry and history of the ongoing merging event in the massive galaxy cluster MACSJ0416.1-2403 (z = 0.397). Our investigation of cluster substructure rests primarily on a combined strong- and weak-lensing mass reconstruction based on the deep, high-resolution images obtained for the Hubble Frontier Fields initiative. To reveal the system's dynamics, we complement this lensing analysis with a study of the intracluster gas using shallow Chandra data, and a three-dimensional model of the distribution and motions of cluster galaxies derived from over 100 spectroscopic redshifts. The multiscale grid model obtained from our combined lensing analysis extends the high-precision strong-lensing mass reconstruction recently performed to cluster-centric distances of almost 1 Mpc. Our analysis detects the two well-known mass concentrations in the cluster core. A pronounced offset between collisional and collisionless matter is only observed for the SW cluster component, while excellent alignment is found for the NE cluster. Both the lensing analysis and the distribution of cluster light strongly suggest the presence of a third massive structure, almost 2 arcmin SW of the cluster centre. Since no X-ray emission is detected in this region, we conclude that this structure is non-virialized and speculate that it might be part of a large-scale filament almost aligned with our line of sight. Combining all evidence from the distribution of dark and luminous matter, we propose two alternative scenarios for the trajectories of the components of MACSJ0416.1-2403. Upcoming deep X-ray observations that allow the detection of shock fronts, cold cores, and sloshing gas (all key diagnostics for studies of cluster collisions) will allow us to test, and distinguish between these two scenarios.", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/stu2425", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1406.3011", "issn": "0035-8711", "number": "4"}, "ADS link": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2015MNRAS.446.4132J", "Publisher link via ADS gateway": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/link_gateway/2015MNRAS.446.4132J/PUB_HTML", "Action": "Scanned and processed (function () {\r\n            var hfSiteUrl = document.getElementById('hfSiteURL');\r\n            var siteUrl = hfSiteUrl.value;\r\n            var subdomainIndex = siteUrl.indexOf('/');\r\n\r\n            hfSiteUrl.value = location.host + (subdomainIndex >= 0 ? siteUrl.substring(subdomainIndex) : '');\r\n        })();\r\n    </script>\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n        <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=54881721 id=\"54881721\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use a joint optical/X-ray analysis to constrain the geometry and history of the ongoing merging event in the massive galaxy cluster MACSJ0416.1\u22122403 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.397). Our investigation of cluster substructure rests primarily on a combined strong- and weak-lensing mass reconstruction based on the deep, high-resolution images obtained for the Hubble Frontier Fields initiative. To reveal the system's dynamics, we complement this lensing analysis with a study of the intracluster gas using shallow <em>Chandra</em> data, and a three-dimensional model of the distribution and motions of cluster galaxies derived from over 100 spectroscopic redshifts. The multiscale grid model obtained from our combined lensing analysis extends the high-precision strong-lensing mass reconstruction recently performed to cluster-centric distances of almost 1\u00a0Mpc. Our analysis detects the two well-known mass concentrations in the cluster core. A pronounced offset between collisional and collisionless matter is only observed for the SW cluster component, while excellent alignment is found for the NE cluster. Both the lensing analysis and the distribution of cluster light strongly suggest the presence of a third massive structure, almost 2\u00a0arcmin SW of the cluster centre. Since no X-ray emission is detected in this region, we conclude that this structure is non-virialized and speculate that it might be part of a large-scale filament almost aligned with our line of sight. Combining all evidence from the distribution of dark and luminous matter, we propose two alternative scenarios for the trajectories of the components of MACSJ0416.1\u22122403. Upcoming deep X-ray observations that allow the detection of shock fronts, cold cores, and sloshing gas (all key diagnostics for studies of cluster collisions) will allow us to test, and distinguish between these two scenarios.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: weak&quot;\">gravitational lensing: weak</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: individual:&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: individual:</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;dark matter&quot;\">dark matter</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;X-rays: galaxies: clusters&quot;\">X-rays: galaxies: clusters</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=54881723 id=\"54881723\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In the course of the past decades, gravitational lensing has become one of the most powerful tools to map the distribution of dark matter, starting with the confirmation of gravitational lensing as the causal origin of the giant arc in the cluster Abell 370 by Soucail et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>). The bending of light by foreground clusters can be observed in two regimes: the strong-lensing (SL) regime, limited to the densest part of the cluster, i.e. its core, and the weak-lensing (WL) regime, in its outskirts. Gravitational lensing allows astronomers not only to directly measure the distribution of the total gravitational mass (dark or luminous), but also to use clusters as \u2018cosmic telescopes\u2019 to image very distant galaxies and to constrain the geometry of the Universe (for reviews, see e.g. Massey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Kneib &amp; Natarajan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). As the most powerful gravitational telescopes, massive clusters are sought-after observational targets.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Occupying the nodes of the cosmic web of large-scale filaments and sheets (Bond, Kofman &amp; Pogosyan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>), massive clusters and, specifically, massive cluster mergers are of particular interest also in the context of structure formation studies. The case of the bullet cluster (1E0657\u221256, <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.3; Clowe, De Lucia &amp; King <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) is exceptional in this context: it shows a merging event of two clusters where the merging direction is perpendicular to the line of sight, maximizing the apparent separation and revealing a clear cone-shaped shock front ahead of the smaller merger component. This rare geometry has allowed studies to separately investigate the distribution and dynamics of the baryonic and dark matter components, e.g. by using a combination of strong- and weak-gravitational lensing (Bradac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). This approach is particularly powerful as SL constrains precisely the location and shape of the cluster core, while WL maps the mass distribution on larger scales. A similar analysis was performed also on MACSJ0025.4\u22121222 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.58; Ebeling et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Brada\u010d et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). Although any given observation captures no more than a snapshot of the complex process of cluster growth, the different dynamical behaviour of collisional (gas) and collisionless matter (dark matter and galaxies) often observed in merging systems has been used to great effect to constrain the three-dimensional trajectories of the merger components (e.g. Clowe et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Ma, Ebeling &amp; Barrett <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Merten et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Hsu, Ebeling &amp; Richard <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). In this paper, we investigate a massive cluster that is both a spectacularly efficient gravitational lens and an active merger.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">MACSJ0416.1\u22122403 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.397, hereafter MACSJ0416) was discovered by the Massive Cluster Survey (MACS; Ebeling, Edge &amp; Henry <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>) and classified as an actively merging system by Mann &amp; Ebeling (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) based on its X-ray/optical morphology. Because of its large Einstein radius, as revealed in <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) observations obtained for programme GO-11103 (PI: Ebeling), MACSJ0416 was selected as one of five \u2018high-magnification\u2019 clusters in the Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with Hubble (CLASH; Postman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The system's highly elongated mass distribution, typical of merging systems, allowed numerous strongly lensed galaxies to be discovered (Zitrin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) in these imaging data. More recently, MACSJ0416 was chosen as one of six targets for the Hubble Frontier Fields (HFF) initiative. Launched by the Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI) in 2013, this observing programme aims to harness the gravitational magnification of massive cluster lenses to study the distant Universe to unprecedented depth. The HFF programme allocates 140 <em>HST</em> orbits to imaging observations of each cluster, split between three filters on the Advanced Camera for Survey (ACS), and four on the Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3), to reach an unprecedented depth for cluster studies of <em>m</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a029 in all seven passbands. The HFF observations of MACSJ0416 with ACS, performed in early 2014, allowed us to identify 51 new multiply-imaged galaxies, bringing the total number of lensed images to a record of 194 (Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The resulting SL mass model confirmed the bimodal mass distribution of MACSJ0416, and constrains the mass within the core region to a precision of better than 1\u2009per\u2009cent.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we extend the analysis of Jauzac et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) by using both strong- and weak-gravitational-lensing constraints to measure and map the mass distribution of MACSJ0416 to larger cluster-centric radii. In addition, we use archival <em>Chandra</em> X-ray data as well as radial velocities measured for over 100 cluster galaxies to investigate the relative motions of collisional and collisionless matter in projection, as well as along our line of sight. The result is a model of the three-dimensional geometry and merger history of this complex system. Our paper is organized as follows: observations of MACSJ0416 are summarized in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2</a>, an overview of our earlier SL analysis is provided in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>, the construction of the WL catalogue is described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>, our gravitational-lensing mass-modelling technique is explained in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>, results are presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6</a>, the dynamical analysis of MACSJ0416 is performed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">7</a>, and, finally, a summary is provided in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec8\"></span><a href=\"#sec8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">8</a>. We adopt the \u039b cold dark matter concordance cosmology with \u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.7, and a Hubble constant <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a070\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>. Magnitudes are quoted in the AB system.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=54881728 id=\"54881728\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 OBSERVATIONS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=54881729 id=\"54881729\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 Pre-HFF <em>HST</em> data</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MACSJ0416 was first observed with the <em>HST</em> using the Wide Field Planetary Camera 2 in 2007 as part of the SNAPshot programme GO-11103 (PI: Ebeling). This observation established MACSJ0416 as a powerful gravitational lens which led to its inclusion in the CLASH programme (PI: Postman; Postman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Hence, MACSJ0416 was observed with <em>HST</em> in 2012 for a total of 20 orbits across 16 passbands, from the UV to the near-IR. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> lists details of these ACS and WFC3 observations, which were used for the pre-HFF analysis of MACSJ0416. All mass models based on pre-HFF data (Coe, Bradley &amp; Zitrin <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Johnson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) are publicly available.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>1</sup></a></p>                        <a id=\"54881731\" scrollto-destination=\"54881731\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of <em>HST</em> observations of MACSJ0416. The HFF observations are highlighted in bold.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>RA (J2000)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Dec. (J2000)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Instrument/Filter<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n 28.7</strong>\u00a0</td><td><strong>ACS/</strong><em>F</em><strong>606</strong><em>W</em>\u00a0</td><td><strong>31\u00a0476</strong>\u00a0</td><td><strong>HFF-13496</strong>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><strong>04 16 08.9</strong>\u00a0</td><td><strong>\u221224 04 28.7</strong>\u00a0</td><td><strong>ACS/</strong><em>F</em><strong>814</strong><em>W</em>\u00a0</td><td><strong>125\u00a0904</strong>\u00a0</td><td><strong>HFF-13496</strong>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/54881731\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=54881732 id=\"54881732\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Hubble Frontier Fields data</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MACSJ0416 is the second cluster to be observed in the HFF programme (GO/DD 13496). Observations with ACS were performed from 2014 January 5 to February 9 in three filters (<em>F</em>435<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>606<em>W</em>, and <em>F</em>814<em>W</em>) for a total exposure time of 20, 12, and 48 orbits, respectively. A summary of these observations is provided at the end of Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. At the time of this writing, imaging of the cluster with WFC3 for the HFF programme had yet to commence.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We applied basic data-reduction procedures to the HFF/ACS data, using <span class=\"small-caps\">hstcal</span> and the most recent calibration files. Individual frames were co-added using <span class=\"small-caps\">astrodrizzle</span> after registration to a common ACS reference image using <span class=\"small-caps\">tweakreg</span>. After an iterative process, we achieve an alignment accuracy of 0.1\u00a0pixel. Our final stacked images have a pixel size of 0.03\u00a0arcsec.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=54881735 id=\"54881735\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3 <em>Chandra</em> X-ray data</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MACSJ0416 was observed with the Advanced CCD Imaging Spectrometer (ACIS-I) on board the <em>Chandra</em> X-ray Observatory on 2009-06-07 for 16\u00a0ks (ObsID 10446, PI: Ebeling), and on 2014-06-09 for 37\u00a0ks (ObsID 16237, PI: Jones). We process these archival data using CIAO v4.6 and CALDB v4.5.9, merging them into a single 53\u00a0ks observation. After examining the light curve of the accumulated count rate for periods of enhanced particle background, we extract a raw image of the cluster in the 0.7\u20137\u00a0keV band and use the <span class=\"small-caps\">ciao</span> tool <span class=\"monospace\">mkexpmap</span> to compute an effective exposure map, taking vignetting effects into account. The raw image, which preserves the recorded photon statistics, is adaptively smoothed using <span class=\"monospace\">asmooth</span> (Ebeling, White &amp; Rangarajan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), requiring 3\u03c3 significance of all features with respect to the local background.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=54881737 id=\"54881737\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-4>2.4 Spectroscopic and photometric redshifts</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">More than 100 spectroscopic galaxy redshifts are available within the field of MACSJ0416. Spectroscopic redshifts from Ebeling, Ma &amp; Barrett (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) are complemented by redshifts obtained for VLT programme 186.A\u20130798 (Balestra et\u00a0al., in preparation). We also make use of the catalogue of photometric redshifts derived by the CLASH team from <em>HST</em> imaging in 16 passbands (second block of entries in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) utilizing the Bayesian Photometric Redshift programme (Ben\u00edtez et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Coe et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). We use of all of these redshifts to select background galaxies for our WL catalogue, as well as for the identification (and removal) of cluster members (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a> for details).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=54881739 id=\"54881739\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 SL ANALYSIS: REVISITING MULTIPLE IMAGES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Since our HFF SL analysis of MACSJ0416 has already been presented in Jauzac et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J14</a>), we here provide only a brief synopsis of the mass model derived and the main results.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Before the HFF observations of MACSJ0416, Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) identified 23 multiple-image systems (corresponding to a total of 70 individual images) in the CLASH data (Postman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The identifications of 10 of these (comprising 36 individual images) were considered less robust. In Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">R14</a>), we included only the most robust systems as well as a few candidate systems showing clear counter images at locations predicted by our preliminary SL analysis. Our final list contained 17 multiply-imaged galaxies (47 individual images). Thanks to the unprecedented depth of the HFF data, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J14</a> were able to dramatically improve these numbers, by discovering 51 new multiple-image systems, bringing our final list of identifications to 68 multiply-imaged galaxies, with a total of 194 individual images. Spectroscopic confirmation however has so far been obtained for only nine systems. The full list of these systems is given in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J14</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using a subset of the 57 most securely identified multiple-image systems, we built a SL parametric mass model using the publicly available <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>2</sup></a> software. The resulting best-fitting model comprises two cluster-scale dark matter haloes and 98 galaxy-scale haloes. The parameters describing this best-fitting mass model are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. We also provide a mass estimate for both components within 20\u00a0arcsec (\u223c100\u00a0kpc).</p>                        <a id=\"54881743\" scrollto-destination=\"54881743\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting pseudo-isothermal elliptical mass distribution parameters for the two large-scale dark matter haloes. Coordinates are quoted in arcseconds with respect to \u03b1\u00a0=\u00a064.038\u20091013\u00a0deg, \u03b4\u00a0=\u00a0\u2212 24.067\u20094860\u00a0deg (yellow cross in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). Errors correspond to the 1\u03c3 confidence level. Parameters in brackets are not optimized. The reference magnitude for scaling relations is <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a019.8. Masses are quoted within an aperture of 20\u00a0arcsec (\u223c100\u00a0kpc).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Component<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: Dec.\u00a0</td><td>1.5 <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{+0.5}_{-0.6}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u221244.5<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{+0.6}_{-0.8}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>e</em>\u00a0</td><td>0.7 \u00b10.02\u00a0</td><td>0.7\u00b10.02\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u03b8\u00a0</td><td>58.0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{+0.7}_{-1.2}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>37.4\u00b10.4\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>r</em><sub>core</sub> (kpc)\u00a0</td><td>77.8<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{+4.1}_{-4.6}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>103.3\u00b14.7\u00a0</td><td>[0.15]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>r</em><sub>cut</sub> (kpc)\u00a0</td><td>[1000]\u00a0</td><td>[1000]\u00a0</td><td>29.5<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{+7.4}_{-4.3}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u03c3 (km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>)\u00a0</td><td>779<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{+22}_{-20}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>955<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{+17}_{-22}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>147.9\u00b1 6.2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>M</em> (10<sup>13</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>)\u00a0</td><td>6.02\u00b10.09\u00a0</td><td>6.12\u00b10.09\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/54881743\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">This model predicts image positions to within an rms error of 0.68\u00a0arcsec, an improvement in precision of almost a factor of 2 over pre-HFF models of this cluster. The total mass enclosed in the multiple-image region is <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>(<em>R</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0320\u2009kpc)\u00a0=\u00a0(3.26\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup>M<sub>\u2299</sub>. This measurement offers a three-fold improvement in precision and drives the statistical mass uncertainty below 1\u2009per\u2009cent for the first time in any cluster. Finally, the statistical uncertainty in the median magnification has been lowered to 4\u2009per\u2009cent. The resulting high-precision magnification map of this powerful cluster lens immediately improves the constraints on the luminosity function of high-redshift galaxies lensed by this system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For more details on our HFF SL analysis of MACSJ0416, we refer the reader to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J14</a>, where the methodology and mass measurements are described in details.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=54881746 id=\"54881746\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 WL CONSTRAINTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we summarize our analysis methodology and then discuss in particular the enhancements to our technique wrought by significant improvements in the data quality brought about by the HFF observations. A more detailed description of the method used to generate the WL background-galaxy catalogue is presented in (Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J12</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=54881748 id=\"54881748\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 The ACS source catalogue</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our WL analysis is based on shape measurements in the ACS/<em>F</em>814<em>W</em> band. Following a method developed for the analysis of data obtained for the COSMOS survey, and described in Leauthaud et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L07</a>), the SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> photometry package (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) is used to detect sources with the \u2018<em>Hot\u2013Cold</em>\u2019 method (Rix et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; J07). It consists of running SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> twice: first with a configuration optimized to detect only the brightest objects (the <em>cold</em> step), and then a second time with a configuration optimized to detect the faint objects that contain most of the lensing signal (the <em>hot</em> step). The resulting catalogue is then cleaned by removing spurious or duplicate detections using a semi-automatic algorithm that defines polygonal masks around stars or saturated pixels. Galaxies are distinguished from stars by examining the distribution of objects in the magnitude (MAG<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\_$|</span>AUTO) versus peak surface brightness (MU<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\_$|</span>MAX) plane (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L07</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J12</a> for more details). Finally, the drizzling process introduces pattern-dependent correlations between neighbouring pixels, which artificially reduces the noise level of co-added drizzled images. Care must be taken to correct for this effect. Because we have used the same Drizzle pixelfrac and convolution kernel parameters as <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L07</a>, we apply the same remedy as <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L07</a> by simply scaling up the noise level in each pixel by the same constant <em>F</em><sub><em>A</em></sub>\u00a0\u2248\u00a00.316, defined by Casertano et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>). The resulting catalogue comprises 4296 sources identified as galaxies and 1171 sources identified as point sources (stars) within a magnitude limit of <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a029.5. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows the magnitude distribution of the detected galaxies and stars.</p>                        <a id=\"54881750\" scrollto-destination=\"54881750\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=YklI5iyaz9qqg-3k8Ye4Ec9wNX8h9jR~kHqTkgP2uJOdJFKCJ9cs2CKmvC97sDn8lI8LpH~5toTvJGkJvtazRepkhHbKRiPXZXblYUhlXQT0Nmb6xq1q4z82-CWVtRZDdYGhVoqDTwPplT9nY3HVg4KDBLvtN8eSkHY8PFTVejyTBrfxjKu8bguJ4S9wTxvXl~NHnq5H0clvPWyw-P6XzUFebVWD-cmnNfVsF4Cv~K7-yaqNXEuAgNSIqRPJnoNFiE559WNoPFRzxGnghVbNak872D0vVy9S7cqD-4jYVI29go~9jjs0Tlb7cQokmTFlg~ChmPlaphIE1cnx9nuWKQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Magnitude distribution of the sources identified as galaxies (solid black) and stars (magenta) resulting from our SExtractor detection.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881750/stu2425fig1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881750\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=roj3MV27hkqT81KHl1BsE66bk60ifDK5RDDjWxoSu8zmaYyQ4jt~bZa6SBDHSBthetZ9dhmGqgwU8ymG~A5I1xAsSFxNgI7BW9KeAgF73vZqUBwByknkBt2ASOzXHtcOTNI51V52HKSbgFdbKVECIIIbtveVKJXegLlv1NTbIAhBYO50cuI~E3QbVA0KWg1Ipdm0tWB9eqY9BO4HetlZqM6kwbfwaPx3Yy~ZsoXlonsGzXtj2HVPE2NoPL5XlpW0B6VCi8ZbSWvuGoqRDV~8YqteBchfNm~G8vaLEB1UATLMV~uBOAS4BbFXZbbxqmr1QhYX8z~vJcosT2Obobsh6w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881750&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Magnitude distribution of the sources identified as galaxies (solid black) and stars (magenta) resulting from our SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> detection.</p></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Since only galaxies behind the cluster are gravitationally lensed, the presence of cluster members and foreground galaxies dilutes the observed shear and reduces the significance of all quantities derived from it. Identifying and eliminating as many of the contaminating unlensed galaxies is thus crucial. As a first step, we identify cluster galaxies with the help of the catalogue of photometric redshifts compiled by the CLASH collaboration, and the spectroscopic redshifts mentioned in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2.4</a>. All galaxies with photometric redshift 0.35&lt; <em>z</em><sub>phot</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.44 are considered to be cluster galaxies. The spectroscopic cluster membership criterion is defined by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\nz_{\\rm cluster} - {\\rm d}z &lt; z &lt; z_{\\rm cluster}+ {\\rm d}z,\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div></div>where <em>z</em> is the spectroscopic redshift of the considered galaxy, <em>z</em><sub>cluster</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.3979 is the systemic redshift of the cluster, and d<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.0104 is the 3\u03c3 cut defined by the colour\u2013magnitude selections presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.2</a>. Only 30\u2009per\u2009cent of the sources in our ACS object catalogue have a photometric redshift. Of these 30\u2009per\u2009cent, 17\u2009per\u2009cent are identified as cluster members or foreground sources following the aforementioned selection criteria. Due to the large difference in depth between the CLASH and HFF observations, the photometric redshift catalogue is not sufficient to identify all the unlensed contaminants in our catalogue. Therefore, taking advantage of the three HFF ACS-band imaging, we use a colour\u2013colour diagram to identify foreground and cluster members (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). Using galaxies with photometric or spectroscopic redshifts, we identify the region in colour\u2013colour space that is dominated by unlensed galaxies (foreground galaxies and cluster members) and define its boundaries by <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub> \u2212 <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.677\u00a076 (<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub> \u2212 <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub>)\u00a0+\u00a00.3; <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub> \u2212 <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.877\u00a076 (<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub> \u2212 <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub>) \u2212 0.76; <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub> \u2212 <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.3. We consequently remove all objects within this region from our analysis. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> shows the galaxy redshift distribution before and after this <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>\u2013<em>F</em>606<em>W</em>\u2013<em>F</em>814<em>W</em> colour\u2013colour selection. This selection is very efficient at removing cluster members and foreground galaxies at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u2264\u00a00.44 \u2013 for the subset of our galaxies that have redshifts, 88\u2009per\u2009cent of the unlensed population are eliminated.</div>                        <a id=\"54881752\" scrollto-destination=\"54881752\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=cNls~PRikY185H0DAnDR4T-DUnkt1viO0rWzSnGru8bEGWbgD92W~cOiK3N8mlQfpVspUVpwwX8-hLYUyueGTTAys8u9rAXdYCTtIq0-IpyGomq9tojtDFUeTZkuSxBVHfkKdrLM~TUizHsNR6VtCJMW~s-5bjVE22Dg11jSC-cl2hoD2yPRp-Hf88ETmaimi0RfcPofY4rF7z~XbO88x0xH1-0wLYbsYlEZ9M7dlRommhkJvtDQqMsvmKd8hqZds-MGkASWi0Lzxr-TaxJ4dnWVS5TJkSCmi8o1ToFX90dPLckDbiGZ7FjjDIxkAk~ZeoVwlY3GdViZRG7LPNr5HA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour\u2013colour diagram (mF435W \u2212 mF814W) versus (mF435W \u2212 mF606W) for objects within the HFF/ACS image of MACSJ0416. Grey dots represent all galaxies in the study area. Unlensed galaxies diluting the shear signal are marked by different colours: galaxies spectroscopically confirmed as cluster members or foreground galaxies (green); galaxies classified as foreground objects because of their photometric redshifts (red); and galaxies classified as cluster members via photometric redshifts (yellow). The solid black lines delineate the colour-cut defined for this work to mitigate shear dilution by unlensed galaxies.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig2.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881752/stu2425fig2.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig2.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881752\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=PRAOJdXgBfd57buFB7A4aeNcn-9D7G8RGKHdBw49rhgnaqE0ijQ3JkHQVgsYI4hM43k6OdSW9vUMePjlMsrJ2VwI5chAtd3gHVMXoAxWyXRwLAw~guZFixYqmpFHYo0Or5ljTYsEh9Yo30b5~Y8xfICFd9wduPUKO-5H4drqwRwsNpy3kcE3Ht64gzXkUVyRu5af-nRvLj4OSFgJLSzEnl553SGTKrLjb0c3sk~LZ9KER30pptQxmk8L~AKOvG4L4zBimg4dlbgzPDXtzQOIVXjGS9TToOm0kVmcLKzSLJg0erNoIWVE9ezvWDWZYTJ4lE8UyRsfJA-8DkUH6nJscg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881752&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig2.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour\u2013colour diagram (<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub> \u2212 <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>) versus (<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub> \u2212 <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub>) for objects within the HFF/ACS image of MACSJ0416. Grey dots represent all galaxies in the study area. Unlensed galaxies diluting the shear signal are marked by different colours: galaxies spectroscopically confirmed as cluster members or foreground galaxies (green); galaxies classified as foreground objects because of their photometric redshifts (red); and galaxies classified as cluster members via photometric redshifts (yellow). The solid black lines delineate the colour-cut defined for this work to mitigate shear dilution by unlensed galaxies.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=cNls~PRikY185H0DAnDR4T-DUnkt1viO0rWzSnGru8bEGWbgD92W~cOiK3N8mlQfpVspUVpwwX8-hLYUyueGTTAys8u9rAXdYCTtIq0-IpyGomq9tojtDFUeTZkuSxBVHfkKdrLM~TUizHsNR6VtCJMW~s-5bjVE22Dg11jSC-cl2hoD2yPRp-Hf88ETmaimi0RfcPofY4rF7z~XbO88x0xH1-0wLYbsYlEZ9M7dlRommhkJvtDQqMsvmKd8hqZds-MGkASWi0Lzxr-TaxJ4dnWVS5TJkSCmi8o1ToFX90dPLckDbiGZ7FjjDIxkAk~ZeoVwlY3GdViZRG7LPNr5HA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour\u2013colour diagram (mF435W \u2212 mF814W) versus (mF435W \u2212 mF606W) for objects within the HFF/ACS image of MACSJ0416. The solid black lines delineate the colour-cut defined for this work to mitigate shear dilution by unlensed galaxies.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig2.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881752/stu2425fig2.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig2.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881752\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=PRAOJdXgBfd57buFB7A4aeNcn-9D7G8RGKHdBw49rhgnaqE0ijQ3JkHQVgsYI4hM43k6OdSW9vUMePjlMsrJ2VwI5chAtd3gHVMXoAxWyXRwLAw~guZFixYqmpFHYo0Or5ljTYsEh9Yo30b5~Y8xfICFd9wduPUKO-5H4drqwRwsNpy3kcE3Ht64gzXkUVyRu5af-nRvLj4OSFgJLSzEnl553SGTKrLjb0c3sk~LZ9KER30pptQxmk8L~AKOvG4L4zBimg4dlbgzPDXtzQOIVXjGS9TToOm0kVmcLKzSLJg0erNoIWVE9ezvWDWZYTJ4lE8UyRsfJA-8DkUH6nJscg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881752&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig2.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour\u2013colour diagram (<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub> \u2212 <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>) versus (<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub> \u2212 <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub>) for objects within the HFF/ACS image of MACSJ0416. Unlensed galaxies diluting the shear signal are marked by different colours: galaxies spectroscopically confirmed as cluster members or foreground galaxies (green); galaxies classified as foreground objects because of their photometric redshifts (red); and galaxies classified as cluster members via photometric redshifts (yellow). The solid black lines delineate the colour-cut defined for this work to mitigate shear dilution by unlensed galaxies.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"54881753\" scrollto-destination=\"54881753\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=qks-zZnbjv2FPtBGnECR0lIqPyxWwEeGg~KTlRDli23WgtfpKkwBA0~~us4bGoCmFo7s6Lzk0DmZ2x1zxeQw1mHY9nxq9gbrfhNRhOVmy4hH2EITI1MHyH1lUw068O12GfmaecK9caTSU-6~4m85zqpHJzX3PqrX1SluSJJuaMjCRir5Q~ob-8m61fcZ9JZPT6ju63mTeRMvL020L~NOFWA1zYPFRp0MJgh1W-M24jcL6O6jtQInE1G4VN24ptcbvGnZ7xNDxkpVm2W7Kalh7pVmAzxyo-bvcn5j~6kiJchbuThsFebPR~jJnKEjHQiFwhvyY9TGyo6k3PTtQ8ntGQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Redshift distribution of all galaxies with mF435W, mF606W, and mF814W photometry from HFF observations, that have photometric or spectroscopic redshifts (dashed black histogram). The cyan histogram shows the redshift distribution of galaxies classified as background objects using the colour\u2013colour criterion illustrated in Fig.\u00a02.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881753/stu2425fig3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881753\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=jYEnLEDQK9w5bRpgiKOBXAdqL7W4bOzkyGbdV1-utsSAiGBXPR5t6vHJC8VtHzvgnlngpeT0PbfQ3uRbVCMtr3MXs6f2szC5Kdl7x3t48W1a4VBDcPCULdlnlkeu8VFoIBP9A3Ah8tIpoGh9b18mbMz9O8ALSqg8vzLQtao0YlD~iYYR9L0Ceb7rrpicH5yoZ0k1C1~I1-bpAuCYBAJURUFMfOgIrEh94qjEBVOuF5TRrunsuojNFEOfwVWSnT-OQSe8FdE7TKM~OBbnIyDAu7U3RFzqnWpjJuoPRWPoU9Zwg5XZ1548JZCqJrMtK7KykEekSE4uiAFk9wjBOQfdfg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881753&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Redshift distribution of all galaxies with <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub>, <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub>, and <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub> photometry from HFF observations, that have photometric or spectroscopic redshifts (dashed black histogram). The cyan histogram shows the redshift distribution of galaxies classified as background objects using the colour\u2013colour criterion illustrated in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=qks-zZnbjv2FPtBGnECR0lIqPyxWwEeGg~KTlRDli23WgtfpKkwBA0~~us4bGoCmFo7s6Lzk0DmZ2x1zxeQw1mHY9nxq9gbrfhNRhOVmy4hH2EITI1MHyH1lUw068O12GfmaecK9caTSU-6~4m85zqpHJzX3PqrX1SluSJJuaMjCRir5Q~ob-8m61fcZ9JZPT6ju63mTeRMvL020L~NOFWA1zYPFRp0MJgh1W-M24jcL6O6jtQInE1G4VN24ptcbvGnZ7xNDxkpVm2W7Kalh7pVmAzxyo-bvcn5j~6kiJchbuThsFebPR~jJnKEjHQiFwhvyY9TGyo6k3PTtQ8ntGQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Redshift distribution of all galaxies with mF435W, mF606W, and mF814W photometry from HFF observations, that have photometric or spectroscopic redshifts (dashed black histogram). The cyan histogram shows the redshift distribution of galaxies classified as background objects using the colour\u2013colour criterion illustrated in Fig.\u00a02.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881753/stu2425fig3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881753\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=jYEnLEDQK9w5bRpgiKOBXAdqL7W4bOzkyGbdV1-utsSAiGBXPR5t6vHJC8VtHzvgnlngpeT0PbfQ3uRbVCMtr3MXs6f2szC5Kdl7x3t48W1a4VBDcPCULdlnlkeu8VFoIBP9A3Ah8tIpoGh9b18mbMz9O8ALSqg8vzLQtao0YlD~iYYR9L0Ceb7rrpicH5yoZ0k1C1~I1-bpAuCYBAJURUFMfOgIrEh94qjEBVOuF5TRrunsuojNFEOfwVWSnT-OQSe8FdE7TKM~OBbnIyDAu7U3RFzqnWpjJuoPRWPoU9Zwg5XZ1548JZCqJrMtK7KykEekSE4uiAFk9wjBOQfdfg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881753&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Redshift distribution of all galaxies with <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub>, <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub>, and <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub> photometry from HFF observations, that have photometric or spectroscopic redshifts (dashed black histogram). The cyan histogram shows the redshift distribution of galaxies classified as background objects using the colour\u2013colour criterion illustrated in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The final validation of our colour\u2013colour selection is done by predicting the colours expected from spectral templates at the redshift of the cluster or in the foreground. We use empirical templates from Coleman, Wu &amp; Weedman (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1980</a>) and Kinney et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) as well as theoretical templates from Bruzual &amp; Charlot (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) for various galaxy types in the Hubble sequences (ranging from elliptical to SB) and starburst galaxies. The location of the colour\u2013colour tracks at <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.44 agree well with our selection region as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> for the Bruzal and Charlot model.</p>                        <a id=\"54881755\" scrollto-destination=\"54881755\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=C-VooqSs~gfKxeGLn0RmSqIYIUDeNYNy87PLcj9vhQNGRCGzXzIUuWx1sx~zK23phCYJO-nYpDA1Zdai2WcutuRysnfvWayGzKCBi-KZYznLVu3U7LMXrMZ8mYBv3aLiJRahq2OBH3MbyiQAkZoau0HUT1502emKWc8cUOnGLtW0dRfoYIMXpPpkYeH4pLad7iAYAsWWgG6joFkiX~ZdArO9t4boDd1h5dmbayMyoquIsZye05I1orH-OB2cgl9MHras4ut3LajaZ~vyL5P1QpG7TakG7Uo-F2dCf1c~eWBL4RUNkfbu9kl21P1VJqh7BZ1CrYyMZU0ZzAA3fX5kjQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour\u2013colour diagram (magF435W \u2212 magF814W) versus (magF435W \u2212 magF606W) as in Fig.\u00a02. The solid black lines delineate the colour-cut defined for this work. The different spectral templates predicted from Coleman et\u00a0al. (1980) and Kinney et\u00a0al. (1996) and the theoretical ones from Bruzual &amp; Charlot (2003) are marked by different colours: elliptical galaxies (red); magelanic irregulars (green); spiral Sa galaxies (cyan); spiral Sb (magenta); spiral Sc (yellow); and S0 galaxies (orange). The dash\u2013dotted curves correspond to a redshift range 0\u00a0&lt;\u00a0z\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.35 (foreground galaxies), and the solid ones to 0.35\u00a0&lt;\u00a0z\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.44 (cluster members).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881755/stu2425fig4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881755\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=fj8hwqdGSM8QdQNfnROdbplDYl-BeI~vSBpGBGjUKRQMmjY~pb7chayArUlhS4BGrctVxH3E0UE41og3SLEw6yp1mZDDPJGfmY4YIhD~Nkvd1zL90dxB1crHvF6AC7OzcMpY6VHLZ0mDn16c8vPusP1Ivsk8jJP0ULV3-ia9BnS8Lci4IR~hnxFyxHnHxwRehyAmbR42wSKjPkn8rqXbxUkbisHV8r3yGZsbDvgJETzVfIuZJ3d1WwAG7OJf3WvnqwFX0eSv4nt1F7cRSrNThI9kfDjS7bSMCJ6m4S85VU4zU~KYhD~R809JJ4iAuN2n2LJvEW65NDP11YD~V9zwug__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881755&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour\u2013colour diagram (mag<sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub> \u2212 mag<sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>) versus (mag<sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub> \u2212 mag<sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub>) as in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1980</a>) and Kinney et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) and the theoretical ones from Bruzual &amp; Charlot (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) are marked by different colours: elliptical galaxies (red); magelanic irregulars (green); spiral Sa galaxies (cyan); spiral Sb (magenta); spiral Sc (yellow); and S0 galaxies (orange).
