(1996) and the theoretical ones from Bruzual &amp; Charlot (2003) are marked by different colours: elliptical galaxies (red); magelanic irregulars (green); spiral Sa galaxies (cyan); spiral Sb (magenta); spiral Sc (yellow); and S0 galaxies (orange). The dash\u2013dotted curves correspond to a redshift range 0\u00a0&lt;\u00a0z\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.35 (foreground galaxies), and the solid ones to 0.35\u00a0&lt;\u00a0z\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.44 (cluster members).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881755/stu2425fig4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881755\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=fj8hwqdGSM8QdQNfnROdbplDYl-BeI~vSBpGBGjUKRQMmjY~pb7chayArUlhS4BGrctVxH3E0UE41og3SLEw6yp1mZDDPJGfmY4YIhD~Nkvd1zL90dxB1crHvF6AC7OzcMpY6VHLZ0mDn16c8vPusP1Ivsk8jJP0ULV3-ia9BnS8Lci4IR~hnxFyxHnHxwRehyAmbR42wSKjPkn8rqXbxUkbisHV8r3yGZsbDvgJETzVfIuZJ3d1WwAG7OJf3WvnqwFX0eSv4nt1F7cRSrNThI9kfDjS7bSMCJ6m4S85VU4zU~KYhD~R809JJ4iAuN2n2LJvEW65NDP11YD~V9zwug__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881755&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour\u2013colour diagram (mag<sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub> \u2212 mag<sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>) versus (mag<sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub> \u2212 mag<sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub>) as in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. The solid black lines delineate the colour-cut defined for this work. The different spectral templates predicted from Coleman et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1980</a>) and Kinney et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) and the theoretical ones from Bruzual &amp; Charlot (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) are marked by different colours: elliptical galaxies (red); magelanic irregulars (green); spiral Sa galaxies (cyan); spiral Sb (magenta); spiral Sc (yellow); and S0 galaxies (orange). The dash\u2013dotted curves correspond to a redshift range 0\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.35 (foreground galaxies), and the solid ones to 0.35\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.44 (cluster members).</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=54881756 id=\"54881756\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Shape measurements and lensing cuts</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Measurements of galaxy shapes are performed using the RRG method (Rhodes, Refregier &amp; Groth <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>). This method has been developed for the analysis of data obtained from space, featuring a small, diffraction-limited point spread function (PSF). It decreases the noise in the shear estimators by correcting each moment of the PSF linearly and only dividing them at the very end to compute an ellipticity. Rhodes et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) demonstrated that the ACS PSF is not as stable as one might expect from a space-based camera. Its size and ellipticity vary considerably on time-scales of weeks due to telescope \u2018breathing\u2019, which induces a deviation from the nominal focus and thus from the nominal PSF which becomes larger and more elliptical. To overcome this problem, Rhodes et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) created a grid of simulated PSF images. From a comparison of the ellipticity of \u223c20 stars in each image to the ellipticities of these model images, the effective focus of the observation can be determined. PSF parameters are then interpolated using the method presented in Massey et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). This technique was used in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L07</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J12</a>. However, it has since been shown that PSF variations occur even between subsequent exposures, and thus a modelling of the PSF for each epoch results in a more accurate estimation of the correction to apply to shear estimations (Harvey et\u00a0al., in preparation).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to handle the multi-epoch images of MACSJ0416, we adapted the RRG pipeline (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L07</a>) to model the average PSF at the position of each galaxy in the stacked image (see Harvey at al., in preparation for more details). To this end, we first locate the positions of the stars in the reference frame of the drizzled image using SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> and both the magnitude\u2013size and magnitude\u2013MU_MAX diagrams. We measure the second- and fourth-order moments of these stars from <em>each</em> exposure and compare them to the TinyTim model for the <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> band. Using the best-fitting TinyTim PSF model, we then interpolate the PSF to the galaxy positions, rotate the moments such that they are in the reference frame of the stacked image, and then take an average over the stack. (Note that our PSF model thus depends on the number of exposures covering a given area and is not necessarily a continuous function across the field.) Since we know the number of exposures that contribute to the image of each galaxy, we can discard shear estimates of galaxies that have fewer than three exposures. Doing so removes all galaxies near the edge of the field and along chip boundaries.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The RRG method returns three parameters: <em>d</em>, a measure of the galaxy size, as well as <em>e</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>e</em><sub>2</sub>, the two components of the ellipticity vector <em>e</em>\u00a0=\u00a0(<em>e</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>e</em><sub>2</sub>), defined as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\n{\\boldsymbol d = \\sqrt{\\frac{1}{2} {(\\boldsymbol {a}^{2} + \\boldsymbol {b}^{2})}}}\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\ne = \\frac{a^{2} - b^{2}}{a^{2} + b^{2}}\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\ne_{1} = e {\\rm cos}(2\\phi )\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\ne_{2} = e {\\rm sin}(2\\phi ).\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div></div>Here, <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are the major and minor axes of the background galaxy, and \u03d5 is the orientation angle of the major axis. The ellipticity <em>e</em> is then calibrated by a factor called shear polarisability, <em>G</em>, to obtain the shear estimator <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\tilde{\\gamma }$|\u2060</span>: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\tilde{\\gamma } = C \\frac{e}{G}.\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>We use the same global measurement of the shear susceptibility <em>G</em> as in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L07</a>: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\nG = 1.125 + 0.04 \\arctan \\frac{{\\rm S}/{\\rm N} - 17}{4}.\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div></div>Finally, <em>C</em> in equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ1\"></span><a href=\"#equ1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">1</a>) is the calibration factor, determined using a set of simulated images similar to those used by STEP (Heymans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Massey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) for COSMOS images, and is given by <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$C = (0.86^{+0.07}_{-0.05})^{-1}$|</span> (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L07</a> for more details).</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The last step in constructing the WL catalogue is to exclude galaxies whose shape parameters are so ill-determined that including them would increase the noise in the shear measurements more than the shear signal. These cuts are the same as the ones used in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L07</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J12</a>, and are quoted here for clarity. </p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Threshold in the estimated detection significance: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\n\\frac{{\\rm S}}{{\\rm N}} = \\frac{{\\rm FLUX\\_AUTO}}{{\\rm FLUXERR\\_AUTO}} &gt; 4.5 ;\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div></div></div></li><li><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">threshold in the total ellipticity: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\ne = \\sqrt{e_{1}^{2} + e_{2}^{2}} &lt; 1 ;\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div></div></div></li><li><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">threshold in the size, as defined by the RRG <em>d</em> parameter: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\n3.6 &lt; d &lt; 30\\; {\\rm pixels}.\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div></div></div></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">As explained in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J12</a>, the requirement that the galaxy ellipticity be less than unity may appear trivial and superfluous. In practice it is meaningful though since the RRG method allows measured ellipticity values to be greater than 1 due to noise, although ellipticity is by definition restricted to <em>e</em>\u00a0\u2264\u00a01. The lower limit in the RRG size parameter <em>d</em> aims to eliminate sources with uncertain shapes, since PSF corrections and thus credible shape measurements become increasingly difficult as the size of a galaxy approaches that of the PSF. The upper limit in <em>d</em> aims to eliminate sources with a size similar to large elliptical cluster members. In addition to applying the aforementioned cuts, and in order to ensure an unbiased mass reconstruction while combining SL and WL, we also remove all background galaxies located in the multiple-image (SL) region, which can be approximated by an ellipse aligned with the cluster elongation as predicted by the SL model (<em>a</em>\u00a0=\u00a075\u2009arcsec, <em>b</em>\u00a0=\u00a036\u2009arcsec, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta = 135\\deg$|\u2060</span>, \u03b1\u00a0=\u00a064.0351\u00a0deg, \u03b4\u00a0=\u00a0\u221224.0745\u00a0deg).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> compares the magnitude distribution of selected background galaxies for the pre-HFF data (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">R14</a>) and the HFF data. The HFF-based catalogue extends to ACS-<em>F</em>814<em>W</em> magnitudes of 29, two magnitudes fainter than the pre-HFF data set. Note that the shown distributions differ also at lower magnitudes. Owing to the greatly increased depth of the HFF data compared to those obtained for the CLASH programme, the contamination by faint foreground and cluster galaxies is much increased too. As a consequence, our colour\u2013colour selection is more drastic and removes more objects in the magnitude range 24\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a026.13 galaxies with <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a024 are still included in our HFF catalogue that were removed from the pre-HFF catalogue of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">R14</a>. The reason is the different colour\u2013colour selection employed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">R14</a>, which was less efficient and required a magnitude cut at <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a024 to remove bright objects. The depth of the HFF images also causes more stars to be saturated, requiring the size of the corresponding masks to be increased; in total \u223c40\u2009per\u2009cent of the ACS surface is masked out as a result. Our final WL catalogue is composed of 714 background galaxies, corresponding to a density of \u223c100 galaxies arcmin<sup>\u22122</sup>. Compared to the catalogue generated by our pre-HFF analysis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">R14</a>), the density of weakly lensed galaxies has almost doubled.</p>                        <a id=\"54881764\" scrollto-destination=\"54881764\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=N5RXwq4Ja74E2N5kblSOlwmplQHgiQ-QQBbOOF8md58qFU~uHf6CpR3I0zCT40F25hrGoAhperW3uiXWFijJhy8YUYzfBLV90N4xrTwhh~M2GBF4qblldYRlIJk8LVFymhkP8zz7RfNOQK-Lhqoy7nd6vRa9voBw5FnDxCnMthYRPIkVC4Q5b7m8mmpaCFNzJy0~9iuRcx4LmdQqAoN4YPtoVRXt-dfFuZkUpv2mhBH9DKPvriarlqfE-c~79DKJafEyNN8DwFDFs2Ndix9W2wa~tmg~oZ07ONd9j~fEU8V3AruFwm25tPsARwFK7gzY2y9ZxJ0EOWdZ3PAKRzAHag__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Magnitude distribution of background galaxies selected for our pre-HFF analysis per arcmin2 (dashed black line; R14), and for this work (orange).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881764/stu2425fig5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881764\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=hriRHtA0hDWJGIw1i8E~erdeZjAkPw6E6cAxE3PWbDQAjzWlt9hAfaQBgtupZqp45VHXmVrsgoQEYu8BFZZqsA~dOqL7FnkxpQcrem4A69AvfxthHYuvq9-B1lkbhiuxGJVjjrcjDObD27FkjuFpdaNjMItWueWVhfo4z6gm2TnSeSyZdm4QMzyr3FE5OidbeJdzX8iFylL9~5dQD3dO3L9900z4zdZGtdbtNkr9TdQkeTtqvhlnl3qoZhiBlDSlOML7Dfi2s5moAO55AB1rwAneiZozNAgxlSAYOqONvdQ0V2plVmSevhXDf2gF~-8elnLCRmRSvb96zeq6wU9z5w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881764&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Magnitude distribution of background galaxies selected for our pre-HFF analysis per arcmin<sup>2</sup> (dashed black line; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">R14</a>), and for this work (orange).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=N5RXwq4Ja74E2N5kblSOlwmplQHgiQ-QQBbOOF8md58qFU~uHf6CpR3I0zCT40F25hrGoAhperW3uiXWFijJhy8YUYzfBLV90N4xrTwhh~M2GBF4qblldYRlIJk8LVFymhkP8zz7RfNOQK-Lhqoy7nd6vRa9voBw5FnDxCnMthYRPIkVC4Q5b7m8mmpaCFNzJy0~9iuRcx4LmdQqAoN4YPtoVRXt-dfFuZkUpv2mhBH9DKPvriarlqfE-c~79DKJafEyNN8DwFDFs2Ndix9W2wa~tmg~oZ07ONd9j~fEU8V3AruFwm25tPsARwFK7gzY2y9ZxJ0EOWdZ3PAKRzAHag__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Magnitude distribution of background galaxies selected for our pre-HFF analysis per arcmin2 (dashed black line; R14), and for this work (orange).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881764/stu2425fig5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881764\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=hriRHtA0hDWJGIw1i8E~erdeZjAkPw6E6cAxE3PWbDQAjzWlt9hAfaQBgtupZqp45VHXmVrsgoQEYu8BFZZqsA~dOqL7FnkxpQcrem4A69AvfxthHYuvq9-B1lkbhiuxGJVjjrcjDObD27FkjuFpdaNjMItWueWVhfo4z6gm2TnSeSyZdm4QMzyr3FE5OidbeJdzX8iFylL9~5dQD3dO3L9900z4zdZGtdbtNkr9TdQkeTtqvhlnl3qoZhiBlDSlOML7Dfi2s5moAO55AB1rwAneiZozNAgxlSAYOqONvdQ0V2plVmSevhXDf2gF~-8elnLCRmRSvb96zeq6wU9z5w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881764&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Magnitude distribution of background galaxies selected for our pre-HFF analysis per arcmin<sup>2</sup> (dashed black line; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">R14</a>), and for this work (orange).</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=54881765 id=\"54881765\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 MASS MODELLING: COMBINING SL AND WL CONSTRAINTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As, in this study, we aim to detect dark-matter-dominated structures outside the SL region, we add a grid-based model to the parametric lens model described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=54881767 id=\"54881767\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 Grid method: combining SL and WL constraints</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In previous work, we modelled the matter distribution with a set of radial basis functions (RBFs) located at the nodes of a multiscale grid, which covered an area slightly larger than observed (Jullo &amp; Kneib <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J12</a>; Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). We complemented this grid-based model with dPIE potentials (El\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) to account for the lensing contribution of cluster members.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this work, we adopt a slightly different approach. We keep the parametric model described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a> fixed at the best-fitting values and then estimate the RBF amplitudes from the WL constraints. By doing so, we appropriately weigh the SL constraints and do not account for them twice. Indeed, an attempt at optimizing the RBF amplitudes with both SL and WL constraints failed to produce physically meaningful results as the SL signal completely dominated the optimization process and essentially overwhelmed the WL data. The parametric model contains two cluster-scale haloes and 146 galaxy-scale haloes, as we extend our analysis to the full ACS field of view (see next subsection). We add a uniform grid of RBFs to these main mass components. Each RBF is axisymmetric, fixed in position and size, and only its amplitude varies, as if they were pixels in an image. The radial profile of each RBF is modelled with a dPIE potential (El\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). The core radius <em>s</em> is set to the distance between an RBF and its closest neighbour, and the cut radius <em>t</em> is assumed to be three times the core radius (Jullo &amp; Kneib <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We tried different prescriptions for the grid resolution. The optimum solution was achieved using a uniform grid with 2741 RBFs separated from each other by <em>s</em>\u00a0=\u00a05.5\u00a0arcsec (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-1-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-1-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.1.1</a> for more details). In addition, we found it necessary to remove the RBFs in the central SL area since, due to a lack of WL constraints, the reconstruction in this region was very noisy. The reconstruction is smooth, thanks to overlapping RBFs.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We sum the contribution of the two components of our model to the observed ellipticity as follows <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\boldsymbol {{e}_m} = M_{\\gamma v} \\boldsymbol {v} + \\boldsymbol {e_{\\rm param}} + \\boldsymbol {n}.\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>Here the vector <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol {v}$|</span> contains the amplitudes of the 2741 RBFs, vector <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol {{e}_m} = [\\boldsymbol {e}_1, \\boldsymbol {e}_2]$|</span> contains the individual shape measurements of the WL sources, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol {e_{\\rm param}}$|</span> is the fixed ellipticity contribution from the parametric model. The vector <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol {n}$|</span> represents the Gaussian noise in the shape measurements, i.e. the intrinsic ellipticity of galaxies and the noise in our measurements of their shapes. The transformation matrix <em>M</em><sub>\u03b3<em>v</em></sub> contains the cross-contribution of each individual RBF to each individual WL source. Each shear component is scaled by the ratio of the distances between each individual source S, the cluster L, and the observer O. The elements of the <em>M</em><sub>\u03b3<em>v</em></sub> matrix for the two shear components are <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\Delta _{1}^{(j,i)} &amp; = &amp;\\frac{D_{{\\rm LS}i}}{D_{{\\rm OS}i}}\\ \\Gamma _{1}^i(|| \\theta _i - \\theta _j ||,\\ s_i,\\ t_i),\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\Delta _{2}^{(j,i)} &amp; = &amp;\\frac{D_{{\\rm LS}i}}{D_{{\\rm OS}i}}\\ \\Gamma _{2}^i(|| \\theta _i - \\theta _j ||,\\ s_i,\\ t_i),\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>where analytical expressions for \u0393<sub>1</sub> and \u0393<sub>2</sub> are given in El\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>, equation A8). Note that the shear in the cluster can be large, and the assumption shown in equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ3\"></span><a href=\"#equ3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>) may not be strictly valid. However, since the parametric model accounts for most of the lensing effect, the contribution to the grid-based model originates primarily in the WL regime.</div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=54881772 id=\"54881772\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>5.2 Modelling of cluster members</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Complementing our grid of RBFs, we add the contributions from 146 cluster member galaxies (presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a>), modelled again as dPIE potentials and selected following the method presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">R14</a>. We define cluster members to be those galaxies that fall within 3\u03c3 of a linear model of the cluster red sequence in both the (<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub> \u2212 <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>) versus <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub> and the (<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub> \u2212 <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub>) versus <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub> colour\u2013magnitude diagrams. The magnitude limit of this sample is <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a023.4.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">These galaxies are then inserted in the model as small-scale pertubators. Their cut radius and velocity dispersions are fixed, and scaled from their luminosities in <em>HST</em>/ACS <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> band. We derive <em>L</em>* in our filter of observation based on the <em>K</em>* magnitudes obtained by Lin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) as a function of cluster redshift. Cut radius and velocity dispersion are then scaled relative to an <em>m</em>*\u00a0=\u00a019.76 galaxy with velocity dispersion \u03c3*\u00a0=\u00a0(119\u00a0\u00b1\u00a020)\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> and cut radius <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{{\\rm cut}}^* = (85\\pm 20)$|</span>\u00a0kpc.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=54881775 id=\"54881775\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-3>5.3 Priors and MCMC sampling</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We sample the huge parameter space with the MassInf algorithm implemented in the Bayesys library (Skilling <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>), itself implemented in <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span>, and described in Jullo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). In summary, this algorithm uses the Gibbs sampling approach in which, at each iteration, the most significant RBFs are first identified and then adjusted in amplitude to fit the ellipticity measurements. The number of significant RBFs is a prior of MassInf, although we have shown in Jullo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) that it has little impact on the reconstruction. We set the initial number of significant RBFs to 2\u2009per\u2009cent, and the algorithm converged to about 4\u2009per\u2009cent. In contrast to previous analyses, we here do not assume that the resulting mass distribution has to be positive everywhere. We found that incorporating such a prior introduces a spurious bias favouring positive values of the mass\u2013sheet degeneracy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The objective function is a standard likelihood function, in which noise is assumed to be Gaussian. The algorithm returns a large number of Monte Carlo Markov Chain (MCMC) samples, from which we can estimate mean values and errors on different quantities (mass density field, amplification field, etc.).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=54881778 id=\"54881778\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-4>5.4 Redshift estimation for background sources</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Of the 714 background galaxies in our catalogue, 236 have a photometric redshift estimated from the CLASH data that allow us to isolate background galaxies. We found the following function to provide a good description of the redshift distribution of these background galaxies: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ5\" content-id=\"equ5\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\mathcal {N}(z) \\propto {\\rm e}^{- (z /z_0)^\\beta }\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(5)</span></div>with \u03b2\u00a0=\u00a01.84 and a median redshift &lt; <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a0= 1.586\u00a0=\u00a00.56\u2009<em>z</em><sub>0</sub> (Natarajan &amp; Kneib <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Gilmore &amp; Natarajan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>).</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition, we split the catalogue into a bright and a faint subsample at the median magnitude <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a026.4. Within the uncertainties given by the number statistics, the resulting two histograms have the same slope. Since <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> allows each source to have its own redshift, we randomly draw (during the initialization phase) redshifts from the fitted redshift distribution for all galaxies without spectroscopic or photometric redshift.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=54881781 id=\"54881781\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 RESULTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We now present our results for the properties of both dark and luminous matter in MACSJ0416, beginning with the distribution of the total gravitating mass as reconstructed by our lensing analysis. All masses for the cluster, as well as density profiles, are measured with respect to the position of the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG), i.e. \u03b1 =04:16:09.144, \u03b4 =\u221224:04:02.95.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=54881783 id=\"54881783\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-1>6.1 Distribution of total mass</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=54881784 id=\"54881784\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-1-1>6.1.1 Grid resolution</h4>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">To assess whether the grid of RBFs presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a> is optimally suited to describe MACSJ0416, we compared the Bayesian evidence resulting from the optimization for grids of different resolution. We remind the reader that the logarithmic Bayesian evidence is given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\n\\log (E) = \\int ^{1}_{0} &lt;\\log (L)&gt;^{\\lambda } {\\rm d}\\lambda ,\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div></div>where the average is computed over a set of 10 MCMC realizations at any given iteration step \u03bb, and the integration is performed over all iterations \u03bb<sub><em>i</em></sub> from the initial model (\u03bb\u00a0=\u00a00) to the best-fitting result (\u03bb\u00a0=\u00a01). The increment d\u03bb depends on the variance between the 10 likelihoods computed at a given iteration, and on a convergence rate that we set equal to 0.1 (see Bayesys manual for details). The increment gets larger as the algorithm converges towards 1.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">To test the impact of higher resolution, we created a uniform grid containing 3883 RBFs separated by <em>s</em>\u00a0=\u00a03.3\u00a0arcsec. We found the resulting model added noise where no structures are detected in the optical. The Bayesian evidence obtained for this high-resolution grid is log\u2009(<em>E</em>)\u00a0=\u00a0\u2212267, compared to log\u2009(<em>E</em>)\u00a0=\u00a0\u2212251 for the grid described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>. We also explored a low-resolution grid, containing 722 RBFs separated by <em>s</em>\u00a0=\u00a011.1\u00a0arcsec. The optimization using this grid resulted in a better Bayesian evidence of log\u2009(<em>E</em>)\u00a0=\u00a0\u2212229, and a similar \u03c7<sup>2</sup>. However, all structures were poorly resolved. Since, in addition, the signal-to-noise ratios in the substructures were equivalent, we discarded this low-resolution model.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=54881787 id=\"54881787\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-1-2>6.1.2 Comparison with previous analyses</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Using the grid method described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>, we reconstruct the mass distribution of MACSJ0416 within the HFF ACS field of view. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows contours (white) of the resulting surface mass density overlaid on the ACS colour image. The mass distribution is highly elongated and features no pronounced substructure at significant distances from the major axis, which is typical of merging clusters. We note as well that the mass distribution is more elliptical than with the SL model. This means that the initial SL model was not only under predicting the mass density, but also the shear in the outskirts. Mirroring the system's morphology in the optical and X-ray regime (magenta and cyan contours in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>) our lensing reconstruction of the total gravitational mass yields again a strongly bimodal distribution. In order to measure the radial mass profile, we define the global cluster centre at \u03b1\u00a0=\u00a064.0364\u00a0deg and \u03b4\u00a0=\u00a0\u221224.0718\u00a0deg (this is the same centre as used in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J14</a> and marked by a yellow cross in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). As a test of the consistency of our mass reconstruction techniques, we can compare the projected mass of <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>(<em>R</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0320\u2009kpc)\u00a0=\u00a0(3.26\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03)\u2009\u00d7 10<sup>14</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub> measured by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J14</a> using exclusively SL features with the value of <em>M</em><sub>SL\u00a0+\u00a0WL</sub>(<em>R</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0320\u2009kpc)\u00a0=\u00a0(3.15\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.13)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub> obtained by our joint SL and WL analysis. The precision attained here is lower since, at this distance from the cluster core, WL constraints already contribute to the total mass. Both methods also yield very similar maps of the mass distribution within the cluster core region.</p>                        <a id=\"54881789\" scrollto-destination=\"54881789\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=bXhH1BoK5rlmky2gHmY6MUrfkp4kp1HwgiQZQTFCt7xa~Kb6mFEUA532IikaDOd5XYGrarASCQWJP5JOXqs3UewwSyKifS8LCMSRRJAbR699V~KXa6eGdQK05MCg97WSTjt4xi-lZYI2HL-dsqNQ75uDmGWXuAKjRxFPFUHz~IQ5eNbFe532rLIiEj8JNb0p2le6xKD2h70f50nm2dXsIQ-3MAYsXAv4SVC57vQpZRariRsN8QBB9c0Fv482FNXYHlbbUvMahuwIRVhvzXtAbvIPVZI~wHMMUJ~7tje6QYyjyaKP8mwLGTadld5AuQHeIVn4P7ZSOm90aCnYJAAHCA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Composite colour image of the galaxy cluster MACSJ0416 created from HST/ACS images in the F814W, F606W, and F435W passbands. Substructures S1 and S2 are marked with orange crosses while the two X-ray peaks, labelled X1 and X2, are marked by cyan crosses.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881789/stu2425fig6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881789\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=Wwe9JQghhrydQT4B3mtjOsS37T8s01JoXVhp6nGgBm2hQVJLeAF~meKWM432FN-C3asdEFZDFfECOOHcDM-DHO65RfGX8J1C0DKh~fnTtY355nkS46Lss2G47hWlbJCy8z0ubKUbkwcaEYS6GQ9z~gr58pIbAbU7RXa0jd89~re-FQDsCXfwhdOIxGxA9iKrTdUSPyWeKZJYflZLt9UIptx-oBKYmGE3jdao3jfkrca98oOdEqEIXR6Okoi1a9i3irNKCO2SYClkKLcmL2lLzXpMaq7jc4~jInn4KNiYRYYl3p5UXGhJXTpIM3R0TAGfhIbuAIzOrJTpKJ8JEDI81w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881789&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Composite colour image of the galaxy cluster MACSJ0416 created from <em>HST</em>/ACS images in the <em>F</em>814<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>606<em>W</em>, and <em>F</em>435<em>W</em> passbands. Mass contours from our gravitational-lensing analysis are shown in bold white, contours of the adaptively smoothed X-ray surface brightness in the 0.5\u20137\u00a0keV band as observed with <em>Chandra</em> are shown in dashed red, while the light distribution is delineated by yellow contours. Substructures S1 and S2 are marked with orange crosses while the two X-ray peaks, labelled X1 and X2, are marked by cyan crosses.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=bXhH1BoK5rlmky2gHmY6MUrfkp4kp1HwgiQZQTFCt7xa~Kb6mFEUA532IikaDOd5XYGrarASCQWJP5JOXqs3UewwSyKifS8LCMSRRJAbR699V~KXa6eGdQK05MCg97WSTjt4xi-lZYI2HL-dsqNQ75uDmGWXuAKjRxFPFUHz~IQ5eNbFe532rLIiEj8JNb0p2le6xKD2h70f50nm2dXsIQ-3MAYsXAv4SVC57vQpZRariRsN8QBB9c0Fv482FNXYHlbbUvMahuwIRVhvzXtAbvIPVZI~wHMMUJ~7tje6QYyjyaKP8mwLGTadld5AuQHeIVn4P7ZSOm90aCnYJAAHCA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Composite colour image of the galaxy cluster MACSJ0416 created from HST/ACS images in the F814W, F606W, and F435W passbands. Substructures S1 and S2 are marked with orange crosses while the two X-ray peaks, labelled X1 and X2, are marked by cyan crosses.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881789/stu2425fig6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881789\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=Wwe9JQghhrydQT4B3mtjOsS37T8s01JoXVhp6nGgBm2hQVJLeAF~meKWM432FN-C3asdEFZDFfECOOHcDM-DHO65RfGX8J1C0DKh~fnTtY355nkS46Lss2G47hWlbJCy8z0ubKUbkwcaEYS6GQ9z~gr58pIbAbU7RXa0jd89~re-FQDsCXfwhdOIxGxA9iKrTdUSPyWeKZJYflZLt9UIptx-oBKYmGE3jdao3jfkrca98oOdEqEIXR6Okoi1a9i3irNKCO2SYClkKLcmL2lLzXpMaq7jc4~jInn4KNiYRYYl3p5UXGhJXTpIM3R0TAGfhIbuAIzOrJTpKJ8JEDI81w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881789&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Composite colour image of the galaxy cluster MACSJ0416 created from <em>HST</em>/ACS images in the <em>F</em>814<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>606<em>W</em>, and <em>F</em>435<em>W</em> passbands. Mass contours from our gravitational-lensing analysis are shown in bold white, contours of the adaptively smoothed X-ray surface brightness in the 0.5\u20137\u00a0keV band as observed with <em>Chandra</em> are shown in dashed red, while the light distribution is delineated by yellow contours. Substructures S1 and S2 are marked with orange crosses while the two X-ray peaks, labelled X1 and X2, are marked by cyan crosses.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> compares the surface density profiles obtained by this analysis with the ones reported by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J14</a> based on their SL mass model. Note the very good agreement at the outer edge of the multiple-image region (shaded area). At larger radii (<em>R</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a0250 <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span>\u00a0kpc) the predictive power of the model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J14</a> weakens, due to the lack of structure massive enough to induce SL. By contrast, the combined SL and WL mass model remains sensitive to the less pronounced density variations at the outskirts of the cluster.</p>                        <a id=\"54881791\" scrollto-destination=\"54881791\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=sCvnUS-xVaxJIzgv43qJ2cP74DIyxV5t21YS~4hwDVdhBeJRG0Jg5fZhlvZi87gejnt59Ez3qrHQf1XvLK70eIlv2bUEfJ3J-Ke31tIGv5-DC1btQPbFrEog9bkQPHWTT-bue9WiIjdX26xoWvgWqJ2nZnCavONpvitTl9yJzHgC90mc7uxtwsSJ73TkTdOYuI2u52QZcDx5n3VfhsJhLxBVhaXlz3ZiVUonqPLLS0Ncj~7CiY4~5wFCMgBV517H-qRdoPnkX4JnlKeYQDK9zso4wa3UJTyawi3B5V04s5U6a79ZSUL60pWpdRQ0pp9qKfB8wJUoY63fkehVTqlgNA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Surface density profile obtained with our comprehensive gravitational-lensing analysis (black). For comparison, we show the surface density profile obtained by J14 based exclusively on SL features (cyan). The shaded light grey area marks the region within which multiple-image systems were found. The two dark grey shaded areas mark the region of substructures S1 and S2. The two green lines represent two different slopes: R\u22121 and R\u22122.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881791/stu2425fig7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881791\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=K8aLgr67Mnhh6QkZG5shd3KZCguHSkXdeCVd8dXQPZS~4JcSTH1cYjFFDi8t1ewdy1BFJ345P7zvV7UKKUCncsQWbf0nR4SUX4hvQG-xmzZstfdPP8kYRLS78~6pbs2-EBCCTgB2IOJf9GwPChUqEINVs~yJha-R9u1d1ChNOEoFJdOLQY4AbyzGLp56hdK3WLxqjPuvvRppVvJdpkw4Ud4sJ9CuopL8FpZRn~Rw6f6GXWm3UhpiUhmjelAWWNrcdsGZI3P3x4vTSkBcfmYw7QkUBe95snzNguM0XPvh2cB9zE9lOsjIrC9ILI3Rd~yZP3m4I31CqEDN8BBhgAL3aQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881791&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Surface density profile obtained with our comprehensive gravitational-lensing analysis (black). For comparison, we show the surface density profile obtained by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J14</a> based exclusively on SL features (cyan). The shaded light grey area marks the region within which multiple-image systems were found. The two dark grey shaded areas mark the region of substructures S1 and S2. The two green lines represent two different slopes: <em>R</em><sup>\u22121</sup> and <em>R</em><sup>\u22122</sup>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=sCvnUS-xVaxJIzgv43qJ2cP74DIyxV5t21YS~4hwDVdhBeJRG0Jg5fZhlvZi87gejnt59Ez3qrHQf1XvLK70eIlv2bUEfJ3J-Ke31tIGv5-DC1btQPbFrEog9bkQPHWTT-bue9WiIjdX26xoWvgWqJ2nZnCavONpvitTl9yJzHgC90mc7uxtwsSJ73TkTdOYuI2u52QZcDx5n3VfhsJhLxBVhaXlz3ZiVUonqPLLS0Ncj~7CiY4~5wFCMgBV517H-qRdoPnkX4JnlKeYQDK9zso4wa3UJTyawi3B5V04s5U6a79ZSUL60pWpdRQ0pp9qKfB8wJUoY63fkehVTqlgNA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Surface density profile obtained with our comprehensive gravitational-lensing analysis (black). For comparison, we show the surface density profile obtained by J14 based exclusively on SL features (cyan). The shaded light grey area marks the region within which multiple-image systems were found. The two dark grey shaded areas mark the region of substructures S1 and S2. The two green lines represent two different slopes: R\u22121 and R\u22122.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881791/stu2425fig7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881791\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=K8aLgr67Mnhh6QkZG5shd3KZCguHSkXdeCVd8dXQPZS~4JcSTH1cYjFFDi8t1ewdy1BFJ345P7zvV7UKKUCncsQWbf0nR4SUX4hvQG-xmzZstfdPP8kYRLS78~6pbs2-EBCCTgB2IOJf9GwPChUqEINVs~yJha-R9u1d1ChNOEoFJdOLQY4AbyzGLp56hdK3WLxqjPuvvRppVvJdpkw4Ud4sJ9CuopL8FpZRn~Rw6f6GXWm3UhpiUhmjelAWWNrcdsGZI3P3x4vTSkBcfmYw7QkUBe95snzNguM0XPvh2cB9zE9lOsjIrC9ILI3Rd~yZP3m4I31CqEDN8BBhgAL3aQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881791&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Surface density profile obtained with our comprehensive gravitational-lensing analysis (black). For comparison, we show the surface density profile obtained by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J14</a> based exclusively on SL features (cyan). The shaded light grey area marks the region within which multiple-image systems were found. The two dark grey shaded areas mark the region of substructures S1 and S2. The two green lines represent two different slopes: <em>R</em><sup>\u22121</sup> and <em>R</em><sup>\u22122</sup>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Pre-HFF SL+WL mass models were also published in Gruen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">R14</a>. Gruen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) present a WL analysis of the Wide-Field Imager SZ Cluster of Galaxy sample based on data collected with the Wide-Field Imager (Baade et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>) on the 2.2\u00a0m MPG/ESO telescope at La Silla. For MACSJ0416, Gruen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) obtain mass values that agree well with ours: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M (R\\,{&lt;}\\,200\\,{\\rm kpc}) = 1.40^{+0.22}_{-0.23}\\times 10^{14}$|</span><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub> (Gruen, private communication) versus our value of <em>M</em>(<em>R</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0200\u2009kpc)\u00a0=\u00a0(1.66\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.05)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. More recently, Umetsu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) published results from a WL analysis of the CLASH cluster sample using Subaru data. For MACSJ0416, Umetsu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) obtain a mass value of <em>M</em>(<em>R</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0950\u2009kpc)\u00a0=\u00a00.98\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.14\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>15</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub> (Umetsu, private communication) that agrees well with our measurement of <em>M</em>(<em>R</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0950\u2009kpc)\u00a0=\u00a01.15\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>15</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. Umetsu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) reconstructed projected mass density profiles for their cluster sample from a joint likelihood analysis of Subaru shear and magnification measurements. The errors include the estimated contribution from uncorrelated large-scale structures projected along the line of sight. Their result is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a> and found to be in good agreement with the density profile obtained by us for MACSJ0416. Finally, the pre-HFF model presented by our team in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">R14</a>, which combines SL and WL constraints but uses a parametric approach similar to the one presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J14</a>, yields <em>M</em>(<em>R</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0200\u2009kpc)\u00a0=\u00a0(1.63\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub>.</p>                        <a id=\"54881793\" scrollto-destination=\"54881793\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=fLeqw56VCWVtwPYZh~mWi6rEgwsV~PjJVsBwoin0GFsRKsHtyykHj9IKwBdru8iLaNgYpoQaWaSQhipFEClur7lNvtR4k4zvyhTZLD6yfSnKVME4P9CXDLo1jpFEUPgcK1ge6kSaw1NLqPZuBLI8-qKsb0QGX2SJhHHGGsFqOoQWrGnBjKIl4-XbxHLiNaHaicOGcvXl0aV4MpoxE2CnfOJIYhhL0k856Kv2G0fhOiACWnLPaeUVdIm0FyRJdFZPkXjGWmlSvkwpXPQJ2lHWCBvgBdZs4hvvLXP30R7X63Rge3q8v7HGISCjiUvMxhtXebvdjC~uhIhsv8Sg6Y~pJw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Surface density profile obtained with our comprehensive gravitational-lensing analysis (black). For comparison, we show the surface density profile obtained by Umetsu et\u00a0al. (2014) based exclusively on WL features (red) derived thanks to Subaru observations (Umetsu, private communication).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig8.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881793/stu2425fig8.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig8.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881793\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=Wt4WZnVku8P4DA6wkYk9QgmyeVE61VBgS-N9LenLdu1yeg~RDDBQhL6A3pN8Xkhiq2tXjnwFFDGiwvP20qGnOtIOm9HBf1EDEpirWY6uJA49ZuTKvzR74DqBdypVzvoq~vaabyjbs5qmYguzalyLEqIfjXyPd3NDKeklhRyzrHk70uYkypSEaMvuiSqpHDDIJnENZoYXl6i1vKGhn8NNhbC2YTd~7jcmc7CK5pVWXkTTPX2kAUlR33vgg6-lciy4rQQlHJ9ZMHU37fbA4jDA23xKE68~-92HQb5mCNTXHdavWj1gJ5WDucSElUZz2EPt~joL5kq-Zobjku3lX7zJpQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881793&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig8.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Surface density profile obtained with our comprehensive gravitational-lensing analysis (black). For comparison, we show the surface density profile obtained by Umetsu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) based exclusively on WL features (red) derived thanks to Subaru observations (Umetsu, private communication).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=fLeqw56VCWVtwPYZh~mWi6rEgwsV~PjJVsBwoin0GFsRKsHtyykHj9IKwBdru8iLaNgYpoQaWaSQhipFEClur7lNvtR4k4zvyhTZLD6yfSnKVME4P9CXDLo1jpFEUPgcK1ge6kSaw1NLqPZuBLI8-qKsb0QGX2SJhHHGGsFqOoQWrGnBjKIl4-XbxHLiNaHaicOGcvXl0aV4MpoxE2CnfOJIYhhL0k856Kv2G0fhOiACWnLPaeUVdIm0FyRJdFZPkXjGWmlSvkwpXPQJ2lHWCBvgBdZs4hvvLXP30R7X63Rge3q8v7HGISCjiUvMxhtXebvdjC~uhIhsv8Sg6Y~pJw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Surface density profile obtained with our comprehensive gravitational-lensing analysis (black). For comparison, we show the surface density profile obtained by Umetsu et\u00a0al. (2014) based exclusively on WL features (red) derived thanks to Subaru observations (Umetsu, private communication).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig8.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881793/stu2425fig8.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig8.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881793\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=Wt4WZnVku8P4DA6wkYk9QgmyeVE61VBgS-N9LenLdu1yeg~RDDBQhL6A3pN8Xkhiq2tXjnwFFDGiwvP20qGnOtIOm9HBf1EDEpirWY6uJA49ZuTKvzR74DqBdypVzvoq~vaabyjbs5qmYguzalyLEqIfjXyPd3NDKeklhRyzrHk70uYkypSEaMvuiSqpHDDIJnENZoYXl6i1vKGhn8NNhbC2YTd~7jcmc7CK5pVWXkTTPX2kAUlR33vgg6-lciy4rQQlHJ9ZMHU37fbA4jDA23xKE68~-92HQb5mCNTXHdavWj1gJ5WDucSElUZz2EPt~joL5kq-Zobjku3lX7zJpQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881793&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig8.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Surface density profile obtained with our comprehensive gravitational-lensing analysis (black). For comparison, we show the surface density profile obtained by Umetsu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) based exclusively on WL features (red) derived thanks to Subaru observations (Umetsu, private communication).</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=54881794 id=\"54881794\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-1-3>6.1.3 Detection of substructure</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As mentioned previously, the SL-only results from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J14</a> are in excellent agreement with those presented here from an analysis that combines SL and WL. The advantages of the latter come to bear particularly in the outskirts of the region probed by the HFF images, where any sufficiently massive substructures will reveal their presence by creating weak gravitational shear in the images of background galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the case of MACSJ0416, we detect two new substructures at high significance in our mass map; their centres are labelled S1 and S2 in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. The projected masses of S1 and S2, estimated within an aperture of \u223c100\u00a0kpc, are (4.22\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.56) and (1.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.20)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>13</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub>, respectively, values typical of galaxy groups. A tentative identification of S1 as a group of galaxies is supported by the presence of a coinciding galaxy overdensity, clearly visible also as a peak in the cluster light distribution (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). For S2, the association with a galaxy group is much less obvious. Physical characteristics of S1 and S2 are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. The distribution of cluster light as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> is obtained by smoothing a map of the flux in the ACS-<em>F</em>814<em>W</em> band from cluster members with a Gaussian kernel (\u03c3\u00a0=\u00a09\u00a0arcsec).</p>                        <a id=\"54881797\" scrollto-destination=\"54881797\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Coordinates, mass within an \u223c100\u00a0kpc aperture, significance of detection, and distance to the cluster centre (<em>D</em><sub>C\u2013S</sub>) for the two substructures detected in the outskirts of MACSJ0416.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA (deg)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Dec. (deg)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M (10^{13}\\, h_{70}^{-1}$|</span>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c3<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>D</em><sub>C\u2013S</sub>(kpc)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>S1\u00a0</td><td>64.016\u00a0542\u00a0</td><td>\u221224.094\u00a0906\u00a0</td><td>4.22\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.56\u00a0</td><td>7.5\u00a0</td><td>580\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>S2\u00a0</td><td>64.060\u00a097\u00a0</td><td>\u221224.063\u00a0636\u00a0</td><td>1.46\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.20\u00a0</td><td>7.3\u00a0</td><td>470\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA (deg)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Dec. (deg)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M (10^{13}\\, h_{70}^{-1}$|</span>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c3<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>D</em><sub>C\u2013S</sub>(kpc)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>S1\u00a0</td><td>64.016\u00a0542\u00a0</td><td>\u221224.094\u00a0906\u00a0</td><td>4.22\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.56\u00a0</td><td>7.5\u00a0</td><td>580\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>S2\u00a0</td><td>64.060\u00a097\u00a0</td><td>\u221224.063\u00a0636\u00a0</td><td>1.46\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.20\u00a0</td><td>7.3\u00a0</td><td>470\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/54881797\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Coordinates, mass within an \u223c100\u00a0kpc aperture, significance of detection, and distance to the cluster centre (<em>D</em><sub>C\u2013S</sub>) for the two substructures detected in the outskirts of MACSJ0416.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA (deg)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Dec. (deg)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M (10^{13}\\, h_{70}^{-1}$|</span>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c3<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>D</em><sub>C\u2013S</sub>(kpc)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>S1\u00a0</td><td>64.016\u00a0542\u00a0</td><td>\u221224.094\u00a0906\u00a0</td><td>4.22\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.56\u00a0</td><td>7.5\u00a0</td><td>580\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>S2\u00a0</td><td>64.060\u00a097\u00a0</td><td>\u221224.063\u00a0636\u00a0</td><td>1.46\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.20\u00a0</td><td>7.3\u00a0</td><td>470\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA (deg)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Dec. (deg)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M (10^{13}\\, h_{70}^{-1}$|</span>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c3<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>D</em><sub>C\u2013S</sub>(kpc)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>S1\u00a0</td><td>64.016\u00a0542\u00a0</td><td>\u221224.094\u00a0906\u00a0</td><td>4.22\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.56\u00a0</td><td>7.5\u00a0</td><td>580\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>S2\u00a0</td><td>64.060\u00a097\u00a0</td><td>\u221224.063\u00a0636\u00a0</td><td>1.46\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.20\u00a0</td><td>7.3\u00a0</td><td>470\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/54881797\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The imprint of these minor mass concentrations on the overall mass density profile can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> in the form of enhancements at \u223c450 <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span>\u00a0kpc (S2), and (much more clearly) at \u223c650\u00a0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span>\u00a0kpc (S1) from the cluster centre. In order to test whether these features are indeed caused by S1 and S2, we follow the same procedure as used in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J12</a> to confirm the detection of the large-scale filament in the field of MACSJ0717.5+3745 and define three triangular regions, anchored at the global cluster centre and extending towards S1, S2, and (for control purposes) a region towards the NW of the field centre that is void of any mass overdensities. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> presents the resulting surface density profiles in these three regions and shows indeed that the excess surface mass density can be attributed to S1 and S2, while no significant variations are observed in the radial surface mass density profile of the control field.</p>                        <a id=\"54881799\" scrollto-destination=\"54881799\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=E7CmeomSJG0POkoI3Be~IWeBxg-v8hExM8jxgJSREgULPQj2Pp7e~BVTrHzZh8~ICiCP-4AWjuFwcWdaay9YYvCMNzMls6R793GqYMsK9UdZ8RoJsiXYOp2i1Aze8OuguOJBM-d7FFPQN0eCaori7gZGp1xkV8hcY5MOb-PG2lRa4qG6tf6wYKZW8GeGPiZLu6jMr8OJzT8dRVrXAZCwmNYAQZHcpLdZ0Y0Tepj-vnU-4gc9VlVWMtJoDz39NRqSBFvDmHnX3oruKf~60ObKFJiglWaa-uDhNwbjFXFVvD66xJ2C3Q6cNYDqpokjmxA89u-JeWhBT9Itq1oEb3VXqA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Surface density profiles obtained with our complete gravitational-lensing analysis (black curve). Finally, we designed a triangular region into which there is no apparent substructures, and it is shown in grey. The two dark grey shaded areas mark the region of substructures S1 and S2.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig9.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881799/stu2425fig9.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig9.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881799\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=3zFSopOpSnNAPRCXPaZrJOqTHepDJp8lDFkh45rzCK2oh8SYihBO8WehyK8R-aqx4IkDAbBWlmPLEVyn9IvQJDs7J~Oqnwrvz7wlyV1LugXNoUxQ78cx2bpyXwRidwXd7O0yY2nFYhr5HNM-2VOCUpcCA~c4yRVjzZd-L0zca-fUwN9AeDHDmzuBdoOYHMzLVUDnZ98NyUnBFl5wRZ1V0yDxosxi06fRong2CT0LkzoUYzD2MX7nyaTm-h~Ujh9E3dMhQAkG4BRyx5HG7Geb-sRHfVqcrNGAqWQflK1B6feCq7ObFyasmYmsnDsFIbHFlxJumShoVZ9GcMtrtQD2Qg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881799&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig9.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Surface density profiles obtained with our complete gravitational-lensing analysis (black curve). In orange we show the density profile we obtain in a triangular region designed from the cluster centre and including S1. We show the same density profile in red but for S2. Finally, we designed a triangular region into which there is no apparent substructures, and it is shown in grey. The two dark grey shaded areas mark the region of substructures S1 and S2.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=E7CmeomSJG0POkoI3Be~IWeBxg-v8hExM8jxgJSREgULPQj2Pp7e~BVTrHzZh8~ICiCP-4AWjuFwcWdaay9YYvCMNzMls6R793GqYMsK9UdZ8RoJsiXYOp2i1Aze8OuguOJBM-d7FFPQN0eCaori7gZGp1xkV8hcY5MOb-PG2lRa4qG6tf6wYKZW8GeGPiZLu6jMr8OJzT8dRVrXAZCwmNYAQZHcpLdZ0Y0Tepj-vnU-4gc9VlVWMtJoDz39NRqSBFvDmHnX3oruKf~60ObKFJiglWaa-uDhNwbjFXFVvD66xJ2C3Q6cNYDqpokjmxA89u-JeWhBT9Itq1oEb3VXqA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Surface density profiles obtained with our complete gravitational-lensing analysis (black curve). In orange we show the density profile we obtain in a triangular region designed from the cluster centre and including S1. We show the same density profile in red but for S2. Finally, we designed a triangular region into which there is no apparent substructures, and it is shown in grey. The two dark grey shaded areas mark the region of substructures S1 and S2.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig9.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881799/stu2425fig9.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig9.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881799\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=3zFSopOpSnNAPRCXPaZrJOqTHepDJp8lDFkh45rzCK2oh8SYihBO8WehyK8R-aqx4IkDAbBWlmPLEVyn9IvQJDs7J~Oqnwrvz7wlyV1LugXNoUxQ78cx2bpyXwRidwXd7O0yY2nFYhr5HNM-2VOCUpcCA~c4yRVjzZd-L0zca-fUwN9AeDHDmzuBdoOYHMzLVUDnZ98NyUnBFl5wRZ1V0yDxosxi06fRong2CT0LkzoUYzD2MX7nyaTm-h~Ujh9E3dMhQAkG4BRyx5HG7Geb-sRHfVqcrNGAqWQflK1B6feCq7ObFyasmYmsnDsFIbHFlxJumShoVZ9GcMtrtQD2Qg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881799&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig9.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Surface density profiles obtained with our complete gravitational-lensing analysis (black curve). In orange we show the density profile we obtain in a triangular region designed from the cluster centre and including S1. We show the same density profile in red but for S2. Finally, we designed a triangular region into which there is no apparent substructures, and it is shown in grey. The two dark grey shaded areas mark the region of substructures S1 and S2.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=54881800 id=\"54881800\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-2>6.2 Distribution of stellar mass</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">To measure the stellar mass distribution, <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>, across the ACS field of view, we use the same method as in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J12</a>. We compute the relation log\u2009(<em>M</em><sub>*</sub>/<em>L</em><sub><em>K</em></sub>)\u00a0=\u00a0<em>az</em>\u00a0+\u00a0<em>b</em>, established by Arnouts et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) for quiescent (red) galaxies in the VVDS sample (Le F\u00e8vre et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>), and adopt a Salpeter initial mass function (IMF).
