Here, <em>L</em><sub><em>K</em></sub> is the galaxy's luminosity in the <em>K</em> band, <em>z</em> is its redshift, and the parameters <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\na &amp; = &amp; -0.18 \\pm 0.03, \\nonumber \\\\\r\nb &amp; = &amp; -0.05 \\pm 0.03. \\nonumber\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We apply this relation to our catalogue of 146 cluster members used in our mass model (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.2</a>). We estimate the <em>K</em>-band luminosity of cluster members observed in the <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> band using theoretical models from Bruzual &amp; Charlot (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) to predict the typical (<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub> \u2212 <em>m</em><sub><em>K</em></sub>) colours. We assume a passively evolved galaxy observed at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.4, with a range of exponentially decaying star formation histories within the range \u03c4\u00a0=\u00a00.1\u20132\u00a0Gyr. This provides a typical colour <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub> \u2212 <em>m</em><sub><em>K</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.14\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04 (AB system). Using the public data obtained from GSAOI observations in the <em>K</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> band (Schirmer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), we confirmed this colour for cluster member galaxies located in the central 100\u00d7100\u00a0arcmin<sup>2</sup> of the cluster. The resulting projected mass density in stars decreases in proportion to the total projected mass density depicted in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>. We measure a mass-to-light ratio across the study area of <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>/<em>L</em><sub><em>K</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.99\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>/L<sub>\u2299</sub>. To compare our results with those obtained by Leauthaud et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) for COSMOS data, we need to adjust our measurements to account for the different IMF used by these authors. Applying a shift of 0.25\u00a0dex to our masses to convert from a Salpeter IMF to a Chabrier IMF, we find (<em>M</em><sub>*</sub>/<em>L</em><sub><em>K</em></sub>)<sub>Chabrier</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.78\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>/L<sub>\u2299</sub> for quiescent galaxies at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.4, in good agreement with Leauthaud et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The fraction of the total mass in stars, <em>f</em><sub>*</sub>, i.e. the ratio between the stellar mass and the total mass of the cluster derived from our lensing analysis within the ACS field of view, is <em>f</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0=\u00a03.15\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.57\u2009per\u2009cent (assuming a Salpeter IMF). The latter value is slightly higher than the one derived by Leauthaud et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The difference might be due to different limiting <em>K</em>-band magnitudes or differences in the galaxy environments probed (the COSMOS study was conducted for groups with a halo masses between 10<sup>11</sup> and 10<sup>14</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub>, and extrapolated to haloes of \u223c10<sup>15</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub>). Another cause might be the use of the analytical Arnouts et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) relation to estimate the stellar mass. As discussed by Ilbert et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), the <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>/<em>L</em><sub><em>K</em></sub> relation used here is only calibrated for massive galaxies, while in practice this ratio varies with galaxy age and colour. Therefore, the Arnouts et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) relation overestimates the stellar masses of low-mass galaxies. Although we do not expect our cluster member sample to be dominated by low-mass galaxies, a bias cannot be firmly ruled out. Finally, we compute the total stellar mass within our study area and find <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0(3.10\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.01)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>13</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. Upcoming HFF data in <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> will provide more direct estimates of the stellar masses.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=54881804 id=\"54881804\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-3>6.3 Intracluster medium</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=54881805 id=\"54881805\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-3-1>6.3.1 X-ray morphology</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows the X-ray contours (in cyan) of the adaptively smoothed X-ray emission as observed with <em>Chandra</em>, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2.3</a>. The X-ray emission shows two peaks (labelled X1 and X2 in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>), located at RA\u00a0=\u00a064.038\u00a0458\u00a0deg, Dec.\u00a0=\u00a0\u221224.067\u00a0361\u00a0deg (X1) and RA\u00a0=\u00a064.029\u00a0792\u00a0deg, Dec.\u00a0=\u00a0\u221224.080\u00a025\u00a0deg (X2), and exhibits a strong elongation in the NE\u2013SW direction. The main peak of the X-ray emission (X1) coincides with the first mass concentration detected in the cluster core by our lensing analysis (C1 in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). However, the second peak (X2) located \u223c45\u00a0arcsec (\u223c250\u00a0kpc) SW of X1, does not coincide with the mass concentration C2 in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and is offsetted to the SW by \u223c15\u00a0arcsec. In the following, we use several models to characterize the gas distribution that gives rise to the X-ray morphology of MACSJ0416.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Acknowledging that the X-ray emission from MACSJ0416 is clearly neither unimodal nor spherically symmetric, we attempt to model the observed X-ray surface brightness distribution as the superposition of two elliptical \u03b2-models in <span class=\"small-caps\">sherpa</span>, leaving the position of the centroids free to vary. This model provides a good description of the data and yields best-fitting centroids for the two components of RA\u00a0=\u00a064.040\u00a0604\u00a0deg, Dec.\u00a0=\u00a0\u221224.066\u00a054\u00a0deg and RA\u00a0=\u00a064.029\u00a0713\u00a0deg, Dec.\u00a0=\u00a0\u221224.081\u00a0072\u00a0deg, respectively. The 1\u03c3 uncertainty of these positions is approximately 2\u00a0arcsec. The model returns best-fitting values of <em>r</em><sub>c1</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0152\u00a0\u00b1\u00a024\u00a0kpc and <em>r</em><sub>c2</sub>\u00a0=\u00a068\u00a0\u00b1\u00a017\u00a0kpc for the core radii of C1 and C2, respectively. The centroid of the main component is thus slightly shifted (by \u223c12\u00a0arcsec) to the NE of the X-ray peak, which is not surprising given the irregular morphology of the X-ray emission. The centroid of the second model component however coincides with the X-ray surface-brightness peak X2.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Proceeding to less massive structures identified in our reconstruction of the mass distribution in MACSJ0416 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>), we also search for X-ray emission from substructure S1, tentatively identified as a galaxy group in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-1-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-1-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.1.3</a>. No evidence of X-ray emission from S1 is discernible in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. In order to obtain a quantitative assessment of the X-ray luminosity and thus gas mass of S1, we add a third, group-sized component (<em>r</em><sub>c</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0100\u00a0kpc, \u03b2\u00a0=\u00a00.7) to our model, tied to the position of S1 as defined in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. We find that the data do not require this third component. The upper limit to the 0.7\u20137\u00a0keV photon flux of 3.2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u22126</sup>\u00a0cm<sup>\u22122</sup>\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> within a 20\u00a0arcsec radius (90\u2009per\u2009cent confidence level) corresponds to an upper limit to the X-ray luminosity and gas mass of mass concentration S1 of <em>L</em><sub>X</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a06.2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>42</sup>\u00a0erg\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> (unabsorbed, 0.1\u20132.4\u00a0keV) and <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>(\u00a0&lt;\u00a020\u2009arcsec)\u00a0&lt;\u00a02.9\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub>, respectively.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=54881809 id=\"54881809\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-3-2>6.3.2 Spectral X-ray analysis</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to further constrain fundamental properties of the intracluster medium (ICM) of MACSJ0416, we examined the X-ray spectrum of the diffuse cluster emission within a radius of 2\u00a0arcmin from the primary X-ray peak (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>). Obvious point sources were excised from the event file prior to the spectral extraction, and a source-free region was defined within the same ACIS-I chip to estimate the local background. We modelled the spectrum with a single-temperature APEC model (Smith et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>) absorbed by the Galactic hydrogen column density, which we fixed at the 21\u00a0cm value of <em>N</em><sub>H</sub>\u00a0=\u00a03.05\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>20</sup>\u00a0cm<sup>\u22122</sup> (Kalberla et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>). Because of the poor photon statistics of the archival ACIS-I observations (\u223c4500 source counts in the 0.7\u20137\u00a0keV band), we grouped the spectral channels to obtain a minimum of 20 counts per bin and used the C-statistic (Cash <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1979</a>) for the fitting procedure. We obtained an average cluster temperature of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$11.0_{-1.3}^{+1.4}$|</span>\u00a0keV and an Fe abundance of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.20_{-0.08}^{+0.09}\\,\\mathrm{Z}_{\\odot }$|\u2060</span>, where the quoted uncertainties represent the 1\u03c3 confidence level. According to the <em>M</em>\u2013<em>T</em> relation of Arnaud, Pointecouteau &amp; Pratt (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>), this temperature corresponds to a total mass of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm 2500} = (4.8_{-0.7}^{+0.9})\\times 10^{14}\\,$|</span><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. With <em>R</em><sub>2500</sub> corresponding roughly to 400\u00a0kpc, this result is consistent with the value of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M(R{&lt;}400\\,{\\rm kpc}) = (4.12\\pm 0.17)\\times 10^{14}\\,h_{70}^{-1}$|</span>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub> measured by our lensing analysis. Most studies (e.g. Nagai, Vikhlinin &amp; Kravtsov <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Nelson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Rasia et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) predict that the lack of thermalization of the gas in violent cluster mergers should lead to an underestimation of the X-ray mass compared to the true mass. However, according to our analysis MACSJ0416 lies on the <em>M</em>\u2013<em>T</em> relation, in spite of ongoing merger activity. While not of great significance in its own right, this result agrees with the low scatter observed around that relation in cluster samples (e.g. Mahdavi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). This is important for future X-ray surveys (e.g. <em>eROSITA</em>), which will use the X-ray temperature as a proxy for cluster mass.</p>                        <a id=\"54881811\" scrollto-destination=\"54881811\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=K-jULF~zre6OxeCvAe73hQQuy0R-TtTbVWaSAJDfAIER-7S8W~bFCcdhZArvaR7~6H2-8BGNI21i~s1tamTENH6cNBzGHQRuBoW8P4iTfr9tutJXz~28hTOMDp09D6LsfhCyOiKhzezvpyWboXo81q-BWFAq0k-FoJh02a10EXf2vsZXW9fCuo4qZPHhMkX-LQ7k-wSVS4pKn0r4VmgaY9BLDgqXoUgEzPBZF9OW0xLtStD~GuKGFoGDBaMrqy4C4m6jaS~kHO3-wahkbdrgUZt0XFU-8oESM3l5N6fBjGCcPqQjDFrW-xk8Tc~HvFyykFosgdz~j~tSGFJM127Xcw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Global Chandra/ACIS-I spectrum of the cluster within 2\u00a0arcmin radius around the X-ray peak. The solid line shows the best-fitting single-temperature APEC model. The red data points indicate the background level as estimated from a source-free region.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig10.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881811/stu2425fig10.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig10.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881811\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=QlWAryfqGjJOeFIG45FBu09pTd~-FBcfxbyMrRMQI2bmm1OpC1~vcoCMBtsrqCg~GPnuO0d4N5kpJHQu~TChPhOX0Pt~ATCU4PhOOdpY6sJdrxwuehTVvvDDx4sxsZQkVaJDVrx4voHrJPR~sjH6T6fcXNW~Cdpp7YW2SHV8t44kn92nO3ou1eJ65SB2Tw4JLv4X0J2hX2wj96Ru7UgQLoELlWB6dqG~3W5sMXwyXjGEF0K~5KhtuANw7qWjo5EUXdVZwesMVuc3jBMY2~Z05if4guuLhHt9oTeQlvU~qh8O0PrrGm1hX5UffSffOcCtiaRRUOF~EglEtQKh~2kXAg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881811&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig10.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Global <em>Chandra</em>/ACIS-I spectrum of the cluster within 2\u00a0arcmin radius around the X-ray peak. The solid line shows the best-fitting single-temperature APEC model. The red data points indicate the background level as estimated from a source-free region.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=K-jULF~zre6OxeCvAe73hQQuy0R-TtTbVWaSAJDfAIER-7S8W~bFCcdhZArvaR7~6H2-8BGNI21i~s1tamTENH6cNBzGHQRuBoW8P4iTfr9tutJXz~28hTOMDp09D6LsfhCyOiKhzezvpyWboXo81q-BWFAq0k-FoJh02a10EXf2vsZXW9fCuo4qZPHhMkX-LQ7k-wSVS4pKn0r4VmgaY9BLDgqXoUgEzPBZF9OW0xLtStD~GuKGFoGDBaMrqy4C4m6jaS~kHO3-wahkbdrgUZt0XFU-8oESM3l5N6fBjGCcPqQjDFrW-xk8Tc~HvFyykFosgdz~j~tSGFJM127Xcw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Global Chandra/ACIS-I spectrum of the cluster within 2\u00a0arcmin radius around the X-ray peak. The solid line shows the best-fitting single-temperature APEC model. The red data points indicate the background level as estimated from a source-free region.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig10.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881811/stu2425fig10.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig10.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881811\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=QlWAryfqGjJOeFIG45FBu09pTd~-FBcfxbyMrRMQI2bmm1OpC1~vcoCMBtsrqCg~GPnuO0d4N5kpJHQu~TChPhOX0Pt~ATCU4PhOOdpY6sJdrxwuehTVvvDDx4sxsZQkVaJDVrx4voHrJPR~sjH6T6fcXNW~Cdpp7YW2SHV8t44kn92nO3ou1eJ65SB2Tw4JLv4X0J2hX2wj96Ru7UgQLoELlWB6dqG~3W5sMXwyXjGEF0K~5KhtuANw7qWjo5EUXdVZwesMVuc3jBMY2~Z05if4guuLhHt9oTeQlvU~qh8O0PrrGm1hX5UffSffOcCtiaRRUOF~EglEtQKh~2kXAg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881811&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig10.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Global <em>Chandra</em>/ACIS-I spectrum of the cluster within 2\u00a0arcmin radius around the X-ray peak. The solid line shows the best-fitting single-temperature APEC model. The red data points indicate the background level as estimated from a source-free region.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">A region of special interest is the core of the NE cluster which appears very compact in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> and perfectly aligned with the associated BCG. To test the hypothesis that this cluster component might host a cool core, we extracted the X-ray spectrum of the two components of MACSJ0416 separately. We measure <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$kT = 10.3_{-0.8}^{+1.1}$|</span>\u00a0keV and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$kT = 13.6_{-1.9}^{+2.2}$|</span>\u00a0keV for the NE and SW subcluster, respectively. Attempts to directly fit an isothermal plasma model to the current archival data within a circle of 10\u00a0arcsec radius of X1 yield unphysical results of either extreme excess absorption of several 10<sup>21</sup>\u00a0cm<sup>\u22122</sup> (equivalent column density of neutral hydrogen) or temperatures well over 20\u00a0keV, i.e. far outside the range that can be constrained with <em>Chandra</em>. Given the poor photon statistics (less than 700 net photons), we do not take these results at face value but rather as indication that an isothermal model is inappropriate. Although we have thus currently no direct spectroscopic evidence of a cool core of the NE cluster component, the data appear to suggest the presence of multiphase gas in this region.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=54881813 id=\"54881813\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-3-3>6.3.3 Gas density and gas mass</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We follow the procedure described in Eckert et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) to estimate the three-dimensional gas-density and gas-mass profiles of MACSJ0416. Accounting for vignetting effects, we extracted a surface-brightness profile for a set of concentric annuli of 5\u00a0arcsec width centred on the primary X-ray peak, and estimated the local background at radii beyond 4\u00a0arcmin. Cluster emission is detected out to \u223c3\u00a0arcmin (\u223c1\u00a0Mpc). The resulting profile was deprojected assuming spherical symmetry using the method of Kriss, Cioffi &amp; Canizares (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1983</a>). We converted the deprojected profile into an emission-measure profile assuming a constant temperature of 7.8\u00a0keV (see above), and inferred the gas-density profile by assuming constant density within each radial shell. Finally, the gas-mass profile was calculated by integrating the gas-density profile in concentric shells.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We measure gas masses of <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>(<em>R</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0500\u2009kpc)\u00a0=\u00a0(3.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>13</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub> and <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>(<em>R</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01\u2009Mpc)\u00a0=\u00a0(8.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.7)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>13</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. In this context, a note is in order regarding systematic effects. Given the irregular morphology of the cluster, the assumption of spherical symmetry might lead to an incorrect gas mass. However, since the morphology of the system beyond the inner regions appears relatively regular, only the gas masses observed in the central regions are significantly affected. Moreover, as stated in Rasia et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), gas-mass measurements are relatively unaffected by the presence of merging substructures, due to the quadratic dependence of the X-ray emissivity on gas density. We thus expect little systematic bias in our measurement, in spite of the unrelaxed morphology of the system.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=54881816 id=\"54881816\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-4>6.4 Baryon fraction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a> shows the fraction of baryons in stars (green asterisks, see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.2</a>) and gas (red diamonds, see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.3</a>) as a function of cluster-centric radius. Both profiles exhibit trends typical for massive galaxy clusters, in which energy input from cluster mergers as well as feedback from active galactic nuclei (Nulsen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) and galactic winds (Metzler &amp; Evrard <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>) raise the entropy of the ICM. As a result, the hot gaseous atmosphere expands, and the gas fraction increases significantly with radius (e.g. Ettori &amp; Fabian <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Vikhlinin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). Conversely, the stars condensate within the massive central galaxies, and the stellar fraction shows the opposite trend.</p>                        <a id=\"54881818\" scrollto-destination=\"54881818\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=zn~waZUr0RkiIXwKBDeydB-wP5izAmoqMH8xAWKauXeb4DmtbX-F3p3EezXUmv5w2ZMsUnZG7yp33Jx~mcKsRYI3JAAXA7k8Py24UbQRPK369oBwzUelBb7-q8Hd-1KzhlHO5IthfsXPO2oBOPB2OyLgkD~YXlm-tqq-XcauMmHR-jJmQBI44qWSvLSnvD94ZIcC~cuI2f7fbH6YmSsoLx0yrkDKvNeNcpWfdCV3VbuQ6jI7PYo61jGfrlEcgR-lu8341caDIgX6L4AKkWxLSO4hyIni3tKn~~n247cB35PpTj7fZJF7~xVMrFfuwsUTmK3avB2jzsA-pHjfYdusOA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Fraction of stars, f*, of gas, fgas, and fraction of baryons, fb present in MACSJ0416. We also plot the baryon fraction measured by Planck (fb\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a9b/\u03a9m\u00a0=\u00a00.1551\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0055), thick black line, and the one measured by Mantz et\u00a0al. (2014) (fb\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a9b/\u03a9m\u00a0=\u00a00.14\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02), thick dashed black line.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig11.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881818/stu2425fig11.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig11.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881818\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=LgkIussCSCTPQ12PhKu0qzjF25tC0x1lalK9-FUQ-wYVuYGegvcFO48KSPLK9jeWNWhbWrmSjV9r4yzeBx8m78tdGWYFcqCjc5azQXddQmamG4eV2IsK2m9EOn8OvdoukM6NVW8qE1laUtM4ec0pcjGf-d4xvXSd9AwgsJ0VISSM1hyfnH10T6LA64Jbp4CE1S6DhlZz05ySeyymKBuDRGn3nPobbOjxFo-i-qxghSEjrHIvZn5f6eqijGcP5gLgzSYoQUGWAFt3V83hsTWygzqNoJOurdcJlg7dBtCmW5V6v0W~u5ecESf~kVrtw5KTarPQM~7hbVcmqZrhN6L3ow__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881818&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig11.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fraction of stars, <em>f</em><sub>*</sub>, of gas, <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub>, and fraction of baryons, <em>f</em><sub>b</sub> present in MACSJ0416. We also plot the baryon fraction measured by Planck (<em>f</em><sub>b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a9<sub>b</sub>/\u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.1551\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0055), thick black line, and the one measured by Mantz et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) (<em>f</em><sub>b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a9<sub>b</sub>/\u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.14\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02), thick dashed black line.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=zn~waZUr0RkiIXwKBDeydB-wP5izAmoqMH8xAWKauXeb4DmtbX-F3p3EezXUmv5w2ZMsUnZG7yp33Jx~mcKsRYI3JAAXA7k8Py24UbQRPK369oBwzUelBb7-q8Hd-1KzhlHO5IthfsXPO2oBOPB2OyLgkD~YXlm-tqq-XcauMmHR-jJmQBI44qWSvLSnvD94ZIcC~cuI2f7fbH6YmSsoLx0yrkDKvNeNcpWfdCV3VbuQ6jI7PYo61jGfrlEcgR-lu8341caDIgX6L4AKkWxLSO4hyIni3tKn~~n247cB35PpTj7fZJF7~xVMrFfuwsUTmK3avB2jzsA-pHjfYdusOA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Fraction of stars, f*, of gas, fgas, and fraction of baryons, fb present in MACSJ0416. We also plot the baryon fraction measured by Planck (fb\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a9b/\u03a9m\u00a0=\u00a00.1551\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0055), thick black line, and the one measured by Mantz et\u00a0al. (2014) (fb\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a9b/\u03a9m\u00a0=\u00a00.14\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02), thick dashed black line.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig11.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881818/stu2425fig11.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig11.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881818\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=LgkIussCSCTPQ12PhKu0qzjF25tC0x1lalK9-FUQ-wYVuYGegvcFO48KSPLK9jeWNWhbWrmSjV9r4yzeBx8m78tdGWYFcqCjc5azQXddQmamG4eV2IsK2m9EOn8OvdoukM6NVW8qE1laUtM4ec0pcjGf-d4xvXSd9AwgsJ0VISSM1hyfnH10T6LA64Jbp4CE1S6DhlZz05ySeyymKBuDRGn3nPobbOjxFo-i-qxghSEjrHIvZn5f6eqijGcP5gLgzSYoQUGWAFt3V83hsTWygzqNoJOurdcJlg7dBtCmW5V6v0W~u5ecESf~kVrtw5KTarPQM~7hbVcmqZrhN6L3ow__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881818&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig11.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fraction of stars, <em>f</em><sub>*</sub>, of gas, <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub>, and fraction of baryons, <em>f</em><sub>b</sub> present in MACSJ0416. We also plot the baryon fraction measured by Planck (<em>f</em><sub>b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a9<sub>b</sub>/\u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.1551\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0055), thick black line, and the one measured by Mantz et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) (<em>f</em><sub>b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a9<sub>b</sub>/\u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.14\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02), thick dashed black line.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The total baryon fraction is shown by orange circles in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>. Within 1\u00a0Mpc from the cluster core, we measure a gas fraction of 0.072\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.007 and a stellar fraction of 0.027\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.004. The total baryon fraction within this aperture is thus\u2009 <em>f</em><sub>bar</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.099\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.008. This value is 5\u03c3 below the cosmic baryon fraction measured by Planck Collaboration XVI (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), <em>f</em><sub>b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a9<sub>b</sub>/\u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.1551\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0055 (black thick line in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>), and also discrepant with the cluster measurement of Mantz et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), <em>f</em><sub>b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a9<sub>b</sub>/\u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.14\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02, at more than 4\u03c3 confidence (dashed black thick line in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This tension might be due to several factors. First, our analysis may have missed a significant fraction of the total stellar mass of the cluster, since the selection of cluster members considers mainly red galaxies. The contribution from less massive (and fainter) star-forming cluster galaxies is not taken into account. In addition, intracluster light can account for 10\u201340\u2009per\u2009cent of the total stellar mass (e.g. Gonzalez, Zaritsky &amp; Zabludoff <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Giodini et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Lagan\u00e1 et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). However, we estimate that, overall, the missing stellar content can contribute at most to 1\u2009per\u2009cent of the total cluster mass. Another explanation is that a large fraction of the baryons resides outside the region sampled in our study. Recent studies (e.g. Simionescu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Eckert et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) have shown that the hot gas fraction continues to increase beyond <em>R</em><sub>500</sub> and eventually reaches the universal baryon fraction. It is likely that a significant fraction of the baryons indeed resides beyond 1\u00a0Mpc from the cluster centre, although the gas fraction of 7\u2009per\u2009cent measured here is still significantly lower than the typical values measured in massive clusters around <em>R</em><sub>500</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a0400\u2009kpc (<em>f</em><sub>gas</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.13; Vikhlinin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Pratt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). Finally, the total mass used to derive the baryon fraction could be overestimated by substructure along the line of sight. Our dynamical analysis of the member galaxies indeed revealed a difference of 800\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> between C1 and C2, and the substructure S1 appears to be largely aligned with our line of sight (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-5\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.5</a>). Since all of the aforementioned biases are known to be present but difficult to account for, we suggest that the deficit of baryons observed in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a> is probably due to a combination of these effects. In particular, it is likely that because of the merging activity a significant fraction of the baryons reside in the outskirts of the cluster, and given the presence of significant line-of-sight structure, the total lensing mass is also likely overestimated by some fraction. Becker &amp; Kravtsov (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) demonstrated that up to \u223c20\u2009per\u2009cent scatter can be expected for WL mass measurements in the case of massive galaxy clusters, due to the presence of correlated and uncorrelated large-scale structures. The impact of these effects is however largely limited to large cluster-centric distances (&gt;3\u00a0Mpc), well beyond the value of \u223c1\u00a0Mpc from the cluster centre to which we map the mass distribution of MACSJ0416 in this study.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=54881821 id=\"54881821\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-5>6.5 Radial velocities of cluster galaxies</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As reported in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.1</a>, the mass map derived by our joint SL and WL analysis reveals four significant mass concentrations: the two main merger components, as well as two smaller components (labelled S1 and S2 in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>) detected at more than 7\u03c3 confidence, that are located about 500\u00a0kpc (in projection) from the overall centre of the cluster.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As part of our attempt to clarify the nature and role of all four of these components in the assembly of MACSJ0416 (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">7</a>), we examine the redshift distribution of galaxies in the respective regions using the spectroscopic data described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2.4</a>. Using the <span class=\"small-caps\">rostat</span> package (Beers, Flynn &amp; Gebhardt <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1990</a>), we find an overall redshift of 0.3980 for MACSJ0416 and a global velocity dispersion of 740\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, based on 106 spectroscopic redshifts. For a first global assessment, we divide the field of view along a boundary that runs perpendicular to the line connecting the main NE and SW cluster components (the apparent projected merger axis), intersecting it at its midpoint. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a> shows the overall distribution of spectroscopic galaxy redshifts (black), as well as, separately, the redshift distributions for the NE (red) and SW regions (blue) thus created. A two-sided Kolmogorov\u2013Smirnov test yields a probability of less than 0.5\u2009per\u2009cent for the hypothesis that the redshift distributions for the NE and SW regions are drawn from the same parent population. Their average redshifts are 0.3990 (NE) and 0.3966 (SW). The difference becomes more pronounced when the modes of the two redshift histograms are considered: 0.4013 (NE) and 0.3938 (SW).</p>                        <a id=\"54881824\" scrollto-destination=\"54881824\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=zSdVMCd9hl9pvUHdGfBibgDa1m18EdJ8DQYQjzFmLEoSlV0xEqAsrCo5jMi6NjvwsCe8FxXSxlci~-Uvevss~AgigtRoU8PcHzJnZj5Dnq7bsiq2v17i~NS1PeHBYqX5nt4dFxy1eWzjDvyqoTRyG0Jh3Wvn~LWi9jbATRFUOAascEljHrraqnGI~ltR9URX0VZy1gK3Wcq4aG4m9fWcZnPeU190k90smMZ2IEwk9vQpgNKQB8v3tCM63hawvRf28DHEm7NsdwN~oyxwHNitYYvCxZRkFcUiCZXvnWGZtMQ4dq~EBnYGJiWGmL1lFdfFLjGjQmZRJsKvDiuGsBOodg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of spectroscopic galaxy redshifts in the field of MACSJ0416. The red and blue histograms show the different redshift distributions in the NE and SW sections of the ACS field, respectively, the green histogram shows the redshift distribution within the substructure S1 (see text for details).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig12.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881824/stu2425fig12.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig12.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881824\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=UxbeSGCRAhmNG5IbSGR1A5~TCq5T9STjJMF-4AvoK3xTV9EhOOJc-rWwLNsssZWO2Jvu6CUdA4-YYVMI6-C-5f29uXB4eVNGafxY4r6YO9GI4o2pBk-gZOfqjfU9ws8dWCSQfd1mGalGIgOLXNVsvmn9vrXID7AIK1Cm~j6Kmw3jjpSnzuWRA1ERZdZD9WUNrM076zWHqRNn0wZE8gjHPKtOxWth~Kt~Xys5LZBbe-WORKpsZGDsfQ40ISkoqBMN8sHHMM0fpZNkdwq1gMHHkp536W6w9LnKLdkUBkkv2WJvXZhtYE3K70HVTW~oHTp34WDgy7NQBTTMyY0yQnUftQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881824&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig12.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of spectroscopic galaxy redshifts in the field of MACSJ0416. The red and blue histograms show the different redshift distributions in the NE and SW sections of the ACS field, respectively, the green histogram shows the redshift distribution within the substructure S1 (see text for details).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=zSdVMCd9hl9pvUHdGfBibgDa1m18EdJ8DQYQjzFmLEoSlV0xEqAsrCo5jMi6NjvwsCe8FxXSxlci~-Uvevss~AgigtRoU8PcHzJnZj5Dnq7bsiq2v17i~NS1PeHBYqX5nt4dFxy1eWzjDvyqoTRyG0Jh3Wvn~LWi9jbATRFUOAascEljHrraqnGI~ltR9URX0VZy1gK3Wcq4aG4m9fWcZnPeU190k90smMZ2IEwk9vQpgNKQB8v3tCM63hawvRf28DHEm7NsdwN~oyxwHNitYYvCxZRkFcUiCZXvnWGZtMQ4dq~EBnYGJiWGmL1lFdfFLjGjQmZRJsKvDiuGsBOodg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of spectroscopic galaxy redshifts in the field of MACSJ0416. The red and blue histograms show the different redshift distributions in the NE and SW sections of the ACS field, respectively, the green histogram shows the redshift distribution within the substructure S1 (see text for details).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig12.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881824/stu2425fig12.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig12.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881824\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=UxbeSGCRAhmNG5IbSGR1A5~TCq5T9STjJMF-4AvoK3xTV9EhOOJc-rWwLNsssZWO2Jvu6CUdA4-YYVMI6-C-5f29uXB4eVNGafxY4r6YO9GI4o2pBk-gZOfqjfU9ws8dWCSQfd1mGalGIgOLXNVsvmn9vrXID7AIK1Cm~j6Kmw3jjpSnzuWRA1ERZdZD9WUNrM076zWHqRNn0wZE8gjHPKtOxWth~Kt~Xys5LZBbe-WORKpsZGDsfQ40ISkoqBMN8sHHMM0fpZNkdwq1gMHHkp536W6w9LnKLdkUBkkv2WJvXZhtYE3K70HVTW~oHTp34WDgy7NQBTTMyY0yQnUftQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881824&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig12.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of spectroscopic galaxy redshifts in the field of MACSJ0416. The red and blue histograms show the different redshift distributions in the NE and SW sections of the ACS field, respectively, the green histogram shows the redshift distribution within the substructure S1 (see text for details).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Proceeding to the much less massive structures S1 and S2, we measure an average redshift of <em>z</em><sub>S1</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.3944 from six cluster members with spectroscopic redshifts within 13\u00a0arcsec (\u223c70\u00a0kpc), but are unable to estimate the redshift of S2 as we presently have no spectroscopic redshift for galaxies even within 15\u00a0arcsec of its centre.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=54881826 id=\"54881826\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>7 THE MERGER GEOMETRY AND HISTORY OF MACSJ0416.1\u22122403</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In the following, we combine our findings regarding the distribution of total gravitational mass, ICM, and cluster galaxies to derive a self-consistent picture of the evolutionary state and three-dimensional merger history of MACSJ0416.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=54881828 id=\"54881828\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7-1>7.1 Evidence</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The bimodal distribution of galaxy redshifts shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a> and a projected separation of the two components of less than 300\u00a0kpc identify MACSJ0416 unambiguously as an active merger. The geometry of the collision, or even the answer to the question whether we observe MACSJ0416 before or after core passage, is not immediately obvious though.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since MACSJ0416 has decoupled from the Hubble flow, the difference between the redshift distributions of galaxies in the NE and SW part of the cluster (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-5\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.5</a>) can safely be attributed to peculiar velocities. The difference between the means (modes) of the distributions corresponds to 500 (1600)\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, while the difference in redshift between the BCGs of C1 and C2 (for simplicity we here adopt the nomenclatures of Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) implies a relative velocity of over 800\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> \u2013 all remarkably high values compared to the global velocity dispersion of the system of 750\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>. With peak collision velocities in massive mergers typically ranging from 1000 to 3000\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, the high relative radial velocity of the two subclusters strongly suggests a merger axis that falls markedly outside the plane of the sky. In a relative sense, C2 is thus moving towards us, while C1 is receding.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For an assessment of the direction of motion of the components of MACSJ0416 in the plane of the sky, as well as of the three-dimensional merger geometry in general, an inspection of the relative offsets (if any) between the collisional and non-collisional cluster components (the intracluster gas, and galaxies as well as dark matter) proves instructive. Binary head-on mergers (BHOM; Mann &amp; Ebeling <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) will feature a binary X-ray morphology before the collision, and a more unimodal morphology after (unless the merger axis falls very close to our line of sight). Offsets between gas and galaxies (and dark matter) will increase throughout the collision, as the non-collisional cluster components proceed unimpeded while the viscous ICM is shocked and slowed during the collision. Regardless of the merger axis, these offsets would be apparent in both participants in a BHOM. This is not the case for MACSJ0416. As shown in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.3.1</a>, collisional (gas) and non-collisional matter (galaxies and dark matter) coincide well for the NE component (C1 and X1), but are clearly displaced from each other (at 7\u03c3 significance) for the SW component (C2 and X2). Since non-collisional matter has to lead collisional matter in a merger, we infer that C2 is moving towards C1 (in projection).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">An intriguing final piece of evidence is provided by the non-detection of structure S1 by <em>Chandra</em>. The lensing mass of S1 of <em>M</em><sub>S1</sub>(<em>R</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0110\u2009kpc)\u00a0=\u00a0(4.22\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.56)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>13</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub> (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>) is substantial, and yet the mass derived for it from the upper limit to its X-ray luminosity of <em>L</em><sub>X</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a03.9\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>42</sup>\u00a0erg\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{2500}&lt;10^{13} h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub>, based on the <em>L</em><sub>X</sub>\u2013<em>M</em> relation for galaxy groups (Sun et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Eckmiller, Hudson &amp; Reiprich <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). This apparent conflict, as well as the absence of hot gas in S1 as evinced by our tight upper limit to its gas fraction of <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.007 (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.3.1</a>), are easily explained though if S1 is in fact part of an unvirialized filamentary structure, almost aligned with our line of sight.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=54881833 id=\"54881833\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7-2>7.2 Tentative merger scenario</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">From the evidence compiled in the preceding section, we conclude that MACSJ0416 is (a) not a BHOM, i.e. the merger proceeds at significant impact parameter, rather than head-on, and (b) that the merger axis is greatly inclined with respect to the plane of the sky. MACSJ0416 is thus reminiscent of the merging system MACSJ0358.8\u22122955 for which Hsu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) conclude that the lower mass component is likely moving along a trajectory that is curved towards our line of sight. The morphology of MACSJ0416 is very similar, except that the offset observed between the gas and the dark matter in the SW component (X2 and C2) goes in the opposite way as seen in MACSJ0358.8\u22122955.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We propose two alternative scenarios for the merger history of MACSJ0416, both of which are consistent with the present three-dimensional geometry as outlined above.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>3</sup></a></p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Scenario #1</em>: the SW component C2, observed near core passage, moves along a curved trajectory that originates in a large-scale filament, part of which is detected as substructure S1 by our lensing reconstruction of the mass distribution. Like for C2 itself, the mean redshift of galaxies near S1 of <em>z</em><sub>S1</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.3944 is lower than that of the NE cluster C1, implying a radial velocity towards the observer of about 1000\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>. The SW region of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> contains a superposition of gas, galaxies, and dark matter from both this putative filament and C2, and hence the differences between the contours of gravitational mass, X-ray surface brightness, and cluster light reflect not only the complex geometry and dynamical history of this system, but are also partly the result of the fact that lensing mass reconstructions collapse the mass of structures along the entire line of sight, virialized or not. Since, in this scenario, the merger of C1 and C2 resembles a \u2018fly-by\u2019 at the time of observation, the trajectory of the SW component has, so far, only grazed the core of the NE cluster which remains largely undisturbed, while ram pressure causes a disassociation between the ICM (X2) and the collisionless constituents (C2) of the approaching cluster (as seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). A sketch of this scenario and of the trajectory of C2 is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a> (dotted line) in a face-on view of the orbital plane.</p>                        <a id=\"54881837\" scrollto-destination=\"54881837\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=0zPMl7~1hN6DyLeIFT9EGHLYVrs-n2pNiRhyyLVpphdvqdAm08lE3z8vSrOa3H1kFk0yXjdQRiziP4XlyjYUJvcD16EY1THhLyUkkixLUO8r7W3wKpGw2Y6Z6-JF-sQWGdZGwPs0s3pgBHkGs3HY4BlcU5TXIecGe1FrUp6ZX0CO3Fzp6joAdrOk-GH9O3KsR~WgS4b-beZqcrId07RyBPV9tqlT8opqFDB26DXVFaqUXoxEcn5JSBOsJjOcrKuZW3wx0ng~iVABqu-t~tRYNHmWXVVPeuFCLQUFOxWekTvcFX7PkHPl4t4cuQfvTn86SQZpawmOdYmmyt04JWEASw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Schematic sketch of our hypothesized merger scenarios in a face-on view of the plane of the collision. The dotted red line marks the trajectory of C2 in our first scenario, in which the system is observed before its first core passage. The solid red line represents the second (preferred) scenario, in which C2 has passed C1 and is viewed after turn-around as it approaches the more massive cluster component for the second time. In this second scenario, filament S1 plays no significant role in the ongoing merger and may be positioned well before the cluster (along our line of sight), outside the area covered by this sketch.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig13.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881837/stu2425fig13.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig13.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881837\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=JKkQtTnrFMSJtifMW8t2SAdOXXEEaXS8yiaHE4hUsNG8QdnYdnEqHn7gtPxpViDEHGbIQvI29GqFvMDQ40vrEpOq4OrCKHpFA3TEozCv41u61riBbz~~yOqTtOgcOKEBIIxLuPHV2kYfvMMJMogTC5fRjua0Ztev12ZfAkjp3veUzWizLzcqD9nqLZYK4KO3EF3CBZRFiM~Q1Bn59mtwh2h-~FpYBUzv7ZDmUVeLFErSF8ic-t6p4AGeFuTokx-B6ZQJYhjKQiiSHWna~GU7z1p9F4a9wfo8LizarlbG9sK28VcfVb0D4IFE3PM3f8BA5qAsFbyciRzKuOypntrurw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881837&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig13.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Schematic sketch of our hypothesized merger scenarios in a face-on view of the plane of the collision. The dotted red line marks the trajectory of C2 in our first scenario, in which the system is observed before its first core passage. The solid red line represents the second (preferred) scenario, in which C2 has passed C1 and is viewed after turn-around as it approaches the more massive cluster component for the second time. In this second scenario, filament S1 plays no significant role in the ongoing merger and may be positioned well before the cluster (along our line of sight), outside the area covered by this sketch.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/m_stu2425fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&amp;Signature=0zPMl7~1hN6DyLeIFT9EGHLYVrs-n2pNiRhyyLVpphdvqdAm08lE3z8vSrOa3H1kFk0yXjdQRiziP4XlyjYUJvcD16EY1THhLyUkkixLUO8r7W3wKpGw2Y6Z6-JF-sQWGdZGwPs0s3pgBHkGs3HY4BlcU5TXIecGe1FrUp6ZX0CO3Fzp6joAdrOk-GH9O3KsR~WgS4b-beZqcrId07RyBPV9tqlT8opqFDB26DXVFaqUXoxEcn5JSBOsJjOcrKuZW3wx0ng~iVABqu-t~tRYNHmWXVVPeuFCLQUFOxWekTvcFX7PkHPl4t4cuQfvTn86SQZpawmOdYmmyt04JWEASw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Schematic sketch of our hypothesized merger scenarios in a face-on view of the plane of the collision. The dotted red line marks the trajectory of C2 in our first scenario, in which the system is observed before its first core passage. The solid red line represents the second (preferred) scenario, in which C2 has passed C1 and is viewed after turn-around as it approaches the more massive cluster component for the second time. In this second scenario, filament S1 plays no significant role in the ongoing merger and may be positioned well before the cluster (along our line of sight), outside the area covered by this sketch.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig13.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/54881837/stu2425fig13.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig13.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"54881837\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/446/4/10.1093_mnras_stu2425/2/stu2425fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639265387&Signature=JKkQtTnrFMSJtifMW8t2SAdOXXEEaXS8yiaHE4hUsNG8QdnYdnEqHn7gtPxpViDEHGbIQvI29GqFvMDQ40vrEpOq4OrCKHpFA3TEozCv41u61riBbz~~yOqTtOgcOKEBIIxLuPHV2kYfvMMJMogTC5fRjua0Ztev12ZfAkjp3veUzWizLzcqD9nqLZYK4KO3EF3CBZRFiM~Q1Bn59mtwh2h-~FpYBUzv7ZDmUVeLFErSF8ic-t6p4AGeFuTokx-B6ZQJYhjKQiiSHWna~GU7z1p9F4a9wfo8LizarlbG9sK28VcfVb0D4IFE3PM3f8BA5qAsFbyciRzKuOypntrurw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=54881837&ar=2893051&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu2425fig13.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Schematic sketch of our hypothesized merger scenarios in a face-on view of the plane of the collision. The dotted red line marks the trajectory of C2 in our first scenario, in which the system is observed before its first core passage. The solid red line represents the second (preferred) scenario, in which C2 has passed C1 and is viewed after turn-around as it approaches the more massive cluster component for the second time. In this second scenario, filament S1 plays no significant role in the ongoing merger and may be positioned well before the cluster (along our line of sight), outside the area covered by this sketch.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Scenario #2</em>: the SW component C2 approaches C1 just like in <em>Scenario #1</em>, but it does so for the second time. In this scenario, C2 does not originate in the large-scale filament S1; rather, C2 originally fell towards C1 from the opposite direction, passing the cluster core at a significant distance before turning around for its second approach. The core of C1 has been significantly disturbed by the earlier passage of C2, but any gas sloshing or shock heating induced by this interaction is almost imperceptible from our viewing angle, as the resulting cold fronts or shock fronts are not viewed edge-on, but are mainly projected on to the core of C1. The trajectory of C2 in this scenario is shown by the solid line in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a>. In <em>Scenario #2</em>, filament S1 may be just behind the cluster (along our line of sight), as indicated in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a>, or far in front of MACSJ0416, well outside the virial regime. The X-ray evidence of multiphase gas in the core region of component C1 (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.3.2</a>) supports <em>Scenario #2</em>, which we thus presently favour.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">More speculatively, and based largely on the apparent lack of a well formed X-ray core, we further propose that the SW component of MACSJ0416 is undergoing its own (minor) merger event. This second merger in the MACSJ0416 system proceeds again at high inclination with respect to the plane of the sky, is in the post-collision phase, and greatly disturbed the ICM, leading to the (unresolved) flat profile around X2. While this potential merger within the SW component of MACSJ0416 can be accommodated by either of our merger scenarios, it would fit more naturally into <em>Scenario #2</em> in which tidal forces during the first core passage may have aided the disruption of C2.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Although the currently available data do not allow us to clearly distinguish between these speculative scenarios, the tantalizing evidence of shock-heated gas in component C1 (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.3.2</a>) strongly supports <em>Scenario #2</em>. An opportunity to discriminate between <em>Scenarios #1</em> and <em>#2</em> will be provided by upcoming deep <em>Chandra</em>/ACIS-I observations of MACSJ0416. Ultimately reaching a cumulative exposure time of over 300\u00a0ks, these observations will be able to detect the presence of shocked gas near X1, as well as between X1 and C2 (clear sign of a previous interaction of the two components), as well as of cold fronts created by sloshing gas near X1. Dramatically improved photon statistics will yield ICM density and temperature maps also around X2 and stand to reveal the true dynamical history of this complex system.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=54881841 id=\"54881841\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec8>8 SUMMARY AND CONCLUSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We present a combined X-ray and optical analysis of the massive galaxy cluster MACSJ0416. Using the deep, high-resolution imaging data obtained by the HFF initiative, we model the mass distribution of the cluster over the <em>HST</em>/ACS field of view using a grid-based method that combines both SL and WL constraints. This lensing analysis is complemented by a study of the diffuse ICM, based on archival (16\u00a0ks\u00a0+\u00a037\u00a0ks) <em>Chandra</em> ACIS-I observation. Finally, we probe the distribution of mass along the line of sight using spectroscopic redshifts of 106 cluster members. We measure the following global properties: an overall galaxy velocity dispersion of 741\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> and compelling evidence of bulk motions of \u223c1000\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> along the line of sight; a total mass of <em>M</em>(<em>R</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0950\u2009kpc)\u00a0=\u00a0(1.15\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>15</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub>; an average mass-to-light ratio of <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>/<em>L</em><sub><em>K</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.99\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03; a gas mass of <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>(<em>R</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01\u2009Mpc)\u00a0=\u00a0(8.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.7)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>13</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub>; an ICM temperature of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$kT = 11.0^{+1.4}_{-1.3}$|</span>\u00a0keV; an Fe abundance in the ICM of 0.20<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{+0.09}_{-0.08}$|</span> Z<sub>\u2299</sub>; and a baryon fraction of <em>f</em><sub>b</sub>(<em>R</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01\u2009Mpc)\u00a0=\u00a00.099\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.008 (5\u03c3 below the cosmological value estimated by the <em>Planck</em> mission). Importantly, our multiwavelength study also constrains the spatial distribution of dark and luminous matter in MACSJ0416 and reveals the presence of a massive (<em>M</em>\u00a0=\u00a0(4.22\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.56)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>13</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub>) but X-ray dark structure that we associate with a line-of-sight filament.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using all observational evidence, we attempt to unravel the dynamical state and merger history of MACSJ0416. Central to our interpretation is the large offset in radial velocity between the two main cluster components, the fact that only the SW component shows a clear offset between collisional and non-collisional matter, and \u2013 possibly \u2013 our discovery of the aforementioned putative line-of-sight filament. We propose two alternative merger scenarios, the general geometry of which resembles that advanced by Hsu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) for MACSJ0358.8\u22122955. Our two scenarios for MACSJ0416 differ from one another primarily with regard to the pre- or post-collision state of the system. In either case, we assume that the NE component of MACSJ0416 is the more massive one. In our first merger scenario, the trajectory of the approaching SW component is slingshot-like, possibly originating in the aforementioned filament and passing the NE component at a significant impact parameter during the imminent first core passage. In our second scenario, the referred-to filament plays no role in the merger, which is much farther advanced than in our first scenario and in fact observed after turnaround of the SW component which now approaches the dominant NE component for the second time. The first passage significantly disturbed the core of the NE component, triggering gas sloshing of a modest cool core and shock heating of the gaseous ambient ICM. Since our spectral analysis of the ICM in the core region of the NE component finds tentative evidence of multiphase gas, we currently favour this second scenario. Travelling along a vector that is highly inclined with respect to the plane of the sky, the SW component appears internally disturbed and may be undergoing a minor merger of its own, regardless of the chosen scenario.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our competing hypotheses regarding the merger history of MACSJ0416 make clear and testable predictions for the X-ray surface brightness and ICM temperature distribution around the NE component and for the region between the two subclusters. Forthcoming deep <em>Chandra</em> ACIS-I observations of MACSJ0416, capable of detecting the signature of sloshing gas and of temperature variations characteristic of ICM\u2013ICM collisions thus hold great promise for a dramatically improved understanding of the formation history of this complex cluster lens.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank St\u00e9phane Arnouts, Olivier Hilbert, and Christophe Adami for fruitful discussions. MJ thanks Ian Smail, and John Stott for their suggestions. We thank Keiichi Umetsu and Daniel Gruen for sharing some of their results with us for comparison. This work was supported by the Leverhulme Trust (grant number PLP-2011-003) and Science and Technology Facilities Council (grant number ST/L00075X/1). MJ, ML, and EJ acknowledge the M\u00e9socentre d'Aix-Marseille Universit\u00e9 (project number: 14b030). This study also benefited from the facilities offered by CeSAM (CEntre de donn\u00e9eS Astrophysique de Marseille (<a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://lam.oamp.fr/cesam/\" target=\"_blank\">http://lam.oamp.fr/cesam/</a>). ML acknowledges the Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS) for its support. JR acknowledges support from the ERC starting grant CALENDS and the CIG grant 294074. JPK and HA acknowledge support from the ERC advanced grant LIDA. DH is supported by a STFC studentship. PN acknowledges support from the National Science Foundation via the grant AST-1044455, AST-1044455, and a theory grant from the STScI HST-AR-12144.01-A. RM is supported by the Royal Society. Based on observations made with the NASA/ESA <em>HST</em>, obtained from the data archive at the STScI. STScI is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc. under NASA contract NAS 5-26555.</p><div content-id=\"fn1\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://archive.stsci.edu/prepds/frontier/lensmodels/\" target=\"_blank\">http://archive.stsci.edu/prepds/frontier/lensmodels/</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://projects.lam.fr/projects/lenstool/wiki\" target=\"_blank\">http://projects.lam.fr/projects/lenstool/wiki</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Both of our scenarios are also in qualitative agreement with the one advanced by Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) who propose that MACSJ0416 is merging along an axis that is only mildly inclined with respect to our line of sight.</p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=54881851 id=\"54881851\" class=\"backreferences-title js-splitscreen-backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list js-splitview-ref-list\"><div content-id=\"bib1\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib1\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib1\" class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"citation element-citation\"><span class=\"person-group\"><div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Arnaud</div> <div class=\"given-names\">M.</div></div>,\u00a0 <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Pointecouteau</div> <div class=\"given-names\">E.</div></div>,\u00a0 <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Pratt</div> <div class=\"given-names\">G. </div>\r\n        </li>\r\n</ul>\r\n \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n            </div>\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleNavLinks widget-instance-OUP_ArticleNavLinks_Article\">\r\n        <ul $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n
