We measure the following global properties: an overall galaxy velocity dispersion of 741\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> and compelling evidence of bulk motions of \u223c1000\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> along the line of sight; a total mass of <em>M</em>(<em>R</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0950\u2009kpc)\u00a0=\u00a0(1.15\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>15</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub>; an average mass-to-light ratio of <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>/<em>L</em><sub><em>K</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.99\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03; a gas mass of <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>(<em>R</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01\u2009Mpc)\u00a0=\u00a0(8.6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.7)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>13</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub>; an ICM temperature of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$kT = 11.0^{+1.4}_{-1.3}$|</span>\u00a0keV; an Fe abundance in the ICM of 0.20<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{+0.09}_{-0.08}$|</span> Z<sub>\u2299</sub>; and a baryon fraction of <em>f</em><sub>b</sub>(<em>R</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01\u2009Mpc)\u00a0=\u00a00.099\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.008 (5\u03c3 below the cosmological value estimated by the <em>Planck</em> mission). Importantly, our multiwavelength study also constrains the spatial distribution of dark and luminous matter in MACSJ0416 and reveals the presence of a massive (<em>M</em>\u00a0=\u00a0(4.22\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.56)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>13</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> M<sub>\u2299</sub>) but X-ray dark structure that we associate with a line-of-sight filament.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using all observational evidence, we attempt to unravel the dynamical state and merger history of MACSJ0416. Central to our interpretation is the large offset in radial velocity between the two main cluster components, the fact that only the SW component shows a clear offset between collisional and non-collisional matter, and \u2013 possibly \u2013 our discovery of the aforementioned putative line-of-sight filament. We propose two alternative merger scenarios, the general geometry of which resembles that advanced by Hsu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) for MACSJ0358.8\u22122955. Our two scenarios for MACSJ0416 differ from one another primarily with regard to the pre- or post-collision state of the system. In either case, we assume that the NE component of MACSJ0416 is the more massive one. In our first merger scenario, the trajectory of the approaching SW component is slingshot-like, possibly originating in the aforementioned filament and passing the NE component at a significant impact parameter during the imminent first core passage. In our second scenario, the referred-to filament plays no role in the merger, which is much farther advanced than in our first scenario and in fact observed after turnaround of the SW component which now approaches the dominant NE component for the second time. The first passage significantly disturbed the core of the NE component, triggering gas sloshing of a modest cool core and shock heating of the gaseous ambient ICM. Since our spectral analysis of the ICM in the core region of the NE component finds tentative evidence of multiphase gas, we currently favour this second scenario. Travelling along a vector that is highly inclined with respect to the plane of the sky, the SW component appears internally disturbed and may be undergoing a minor merger of its own, regardless of the chosen scenario.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our competing hypotheses regarding the merger history of MACSJ0416 make clear and testable predictions for the X-ray surface brightness and ICM temperature distribution around the NE component and for the region between the two subclusters. Forthcoming deep <em>Chandra</em> ACIS-I observations of MACSJ0416, capable of detecting the signature of sloshing gas and of temperature variations characteristic of ICM\u2013ICM collisions thus hold great promise for a dramatically improved understanding of the formation history of this complex cluster lens.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank St\u00e9phane Arnouts, Olivier Hilbert, and Christophe Adami for fruitful discussions. MJ thanks Ian Smail, and John Stott for their suggestions. We thank Keiichi Umetsu and Daniel Gruen for sharing some of their results with us for comparison. This work was supported by the Leverhulme Trust (grant number PLP-2011-003) and Science and Technology Facilities Council (grant number ST/L00075X/1). MJ, ML, and EJ acknowledge the M\u00e9socentre d'Aix-Marseille Universit\u00e9 (project number: 14b030). This study also benefited from the facilities offered by CeSAM (CEntre de donn\u00e9eS Astrophysique de Marseille (<a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://lam.oamp.fr/cesam/\" target=\"_blank\">http://lam.oamp.fr/cesam/</a>). ML acknowledges the Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS) for its support. JR acknowledges support from the ERC starting grant CALENDS and the CIG grant 294074. JPK and HA acknowledge support from the ERC advanced grant LIDA. DH is supported by a STFC studentship. PN acknowledges support from the National Science Foundation via the grant AST-1044455, AST-1044455, and a theory grant from the STScI HST-AR-12144.01-A. RM is supported by the Royal Society. Based on observations made with the NASA/ESA <em>HST</em>, obtained from the data archive at the STScI. STScI is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc. under NASA contract NAS 5-26555.</p><div content-id=\"fn1\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://archive.stsci.edu/prepds/frontier/lensmodels/\" target=\"_blank\">http://archive.stsci.edu/prepds/frontier/lensmodels/</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://projects.lam.fr/projects/lenstool/wiki\" target=\"_blank\">http://projects.lam.fr/projects/lenstool/wiki</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Both of our scenarios are also in qualitative agreement with the one advanced by Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) who propose that MACSJ0416 is merging along an axis that is only mildly inclined with respect to our line of sight.</p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=54881851 id=\"54881851\" class=\"backreferences-title js-splitscreen-backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list js-splitview-ref-list\"><div content-id=\"bib1\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib1\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib1\" class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"citation element-citation\"><span class=\"person-group\"><div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Arnaud</div> <div class=\"given-names\">M.</div></div>,\u00a0 <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Pointecouteau</div> <div class=\"given-names\">E.</div></div>,\u00a0 <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Pratt</div> <div class=\"given-names\">G. </div>\r\n\r\n\r\n</body>\r\n</html>\r\n\r\n", "Status": "Complete", "Action": "Scanned all subtables", "Table captions or footers": {"Overview": " class=\"chapter-para\">The imprint of these minor mass concentrations on the overall mass density profile can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> in the form of enhancements at \u223c450 <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span>\u00a0kpc (S2), and (much more clearly) at \u223c650\u00a0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$h_{70}^{-1}$|</span>\u00a0kpc (S1) from the cluster centre. In order to test whether these features are indeed caused by S1 and S2, we follow the same procedure as used in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J12</a> to confirm the detection of the large-scale filament in the field of MACSJ0717.5+3745 and define three triangular regions, anchored at the global cluster centre and extending towards S1, S2, and (for control purposes) a region towards the NW of the field centre that is void of any mass overdensities. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> presents the resulting surface density profiles in these three regions and shows indeed that the excess surface mass density can be attributed to S1 and S2, while no significant variations are observed in the radial surface mass density profile of the control field."}, "Pandas format": {"Table 2": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting pseudo-isothermal elliptical mass distribution parameters for the two large-scale dark matter haloes. Coordinates are quoted in arcseconds with respect to \u03b1\u00a0=\u00a064.038\u20091013\u00a0deg, \u03b4\u00a0=\u00a0\u2212 24.067\u20094860\u00a0deg (yellow cross in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span>6). Errors correspond to the 1\u03c3 confidence level. Parameters in brackets are not optimized. The reference magnitude for scaling relations is <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a019.8.
